reviewText:
Hands down the present incarnation of Lara Croft is the best-written Triple-A protagonist I have ever seen. Even if that seems like a pretty low bar to clear, Crystal Dynamics' writing clears that bar by a very wide margin, and sets less of a benchmark than they do write the book on how to do good characters and character development in gaming.

The thing I have enjoyed about both titles in the Tomb Raider reboot is that more than any other Triple-A titles their character stories carry the game through more than any single element of the graphics or gameplay. Lara Croft is strong, determined, and single-minded, but she is by no means perfect or indeed unaffected by her previous trials because by the same turns she is proving to be obsessed, brooding, and also reckless.

The beauty of all of Lara's character nuances lie in the subtleties. She has survived the Dragon's Triangle, but not without being changed. Lara's view of the world has been tilted, the illusions that everyone carries around with them are sliding away from her, and this comes out in her growing obsession with her Father's research, which is driving a wedge between her and everyone else she knows. This is a character story that is heading for a huge confrontation with the demons Lara keeps accumulating, and that story is going to be one hell of a battle.

When Lara washed up on Yamatai she suffered through her ordeal as any of us would: fearfully, desperately and at times through tears and hysteria. This time around I was expecting a more mature Lara, I got it. I was expecting a tougher Lara, I got that too. I was expecting a Lara that was a little more suspicious, more attuned to threats, and I even got that. What I wasn't really expecting was a Lara who had gone past the point of confidence and in the other direction. I was expecting the stakes to be higher, and they are to an extent, but Crystal Dynamics have managed to largely sidestep this potential pitfall in the way the story of Lara's search is told through her father's old audio logs and Lara's own fireside diaries.

Lara Croft: survivor, archaeologist, Jill of all trades. She is still out her depth, but this time it's not the environment or the crazy cultists who have her overwhelmed. This time Lara Croft is overwhelmed by Lara Croft. Held hostage and pulled ever onward by an obession she may not be able to handle. This is how Rise of the Tomb Raider succeeds at avoiding the standard escalation trope through making the story about Lara, rather than simply about its gorgeous vistas, paramilitary groups, and ancient conspiracies. All the standard fare that has been part of the Tomb Raider cannon for two decades is there, but the element of realism that comes from placing the ideas of mental toughness and psychological/emotional vulnerability on separate scales adds so much extra depth to the storytelling without crowding out the current game's plot.

The core gameplay vis-a-vis Lara's movement and actions hasn't really changed from the reboot, but if you've played the original the storytelling makes this feel exactly like slipping into the same old patterns, so from the getgo Lara is ready to outrun black helicopters, tidal waves, crumbling temples and even collapsing mountainsides. The opening scenes recall all of the expertise Lara had accumulated by the end of her trial by fire on Yamatai, and the landscape and pacing also recall Lara's final panicked scrabble up the temple mountain to rescue Sam from Matthias. A walk down memory lane has never been so subtle, so visceral, and so accessible. Without a single black and white vignette, followers of Lara's previous adventure will find all of their memories being triggered, all while newcomers are getting their feet wet.

All the gameplay updates take place in the weapons, apparel, traps, and crafting mechanics and this too adds more weight to the story: Lara has been busy since Yamatai, she's refined her bushcraft and her jury-rigging skills, and become more proficient at living off the land. Her climbing axe, a firesteel, a length of rope, is all Lara needs to survive. I was worried that I would be taken back to square one in terms of Lara's skills, there is still a difficulty tree to climb after all. But rather than simply take us back to square one in terms of abilities, Lara gets a few extras from the getgo that she didn't have before. Being able to 'death-from-above' enemies or ambush them from the bushes from the very beginning, reminds us that Lara is a well-heeled adventurer, and the skills she is still to develop are a level above her current expertise. So all in all, the gameplay changes make sense.

I was a little worried that all the resources and crafting would be overwhelming and time-consuming, but after a half hour getting to grips with accumulating resources I found it quite simple. Crystal Dynamics have taken the highlighting element that illuminates useful objects from their first offering and simply expanded on the number of different items one can collect, moreover most of the resources stick out normally anyhow, and there are enough of them on your way from A to B without feeling like you're being sidetracked. The amount of complexity is just right and unlike other titles with similar elements, I have yet to feel as though I am dividing my time between crafting and advancing the story. Once again Crystal Dynamics are writing the book on how to do things right.

If you like good character stories, but every once in a while you like to play a run-and-gun-hack-and-slash game to unwind with, Rise of the Tomb Raider manages to cram in the best of both of these worlds without sacrificing on either, and the story really does leave its fingerprints on everything. Do yourself a favour and buy this game, dive right in and get lost in it.

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider pretty much takes everything from the 2013 TR and adds some extra stuff. It's the same type of gameplay with less quicktime events but with the same action packed, everything-is-falling-apart-around-me feeling you get during the whole duration of your exploration with Lara.

Even though RotTR requires a bit beefier rig, it still runs perfectly smooth even with all the eyecandy turned on. Also - the new hair physics look awesome and natural with no bugs or random clipping like the TressFX had back in TR2013.

The game takes you on a journey to find an artifact of power that grants immortality. The same artefact Lara's father was searching for, and in the end - died for. Driven by her father's last words you take Lara on her first journey through the snowy areas of RotTR.

You get the same, a bit upgraded, arsenal of weapons and skills that you unlock through gameplay as before - but this time you can do extra side missions and optional tombs to unlock special skills and abilities otherwise unavailable.

The only bad side of the game is the usual half-dumb AI of the guards Lara encounters (although I was surprised to notice how the shielded guards actually move the shield up/down depending on your aiming), and the fact that you will spend most of the game in a snowy area. A bit of diversity would be nice.

One other thing that kinda stood out was occasional situations where Lara goes into Rambo mode. I understood her killing rampage outburst in TR2013 (being all alone and inexperienced on an island full of lunatics), but in RotTR she does the same thing once or twice when she could easily do it stealthy...

Apart from that - the game is bug free and pretty much a perfect sequel to the TR reboot.

Also - the game ends in a cliffhanger obviously suggesting a new TR that will directly continue Lara's story from RotTR!

reviewText:
A good improvement from Tomb Raider, game feels a bit more open and the action is pretty good. Story advanced away from the original series by the decisions made in this game, even if the mythical stuff remains. The game itself looks amazing, the sound design is great and Lara feels very real. Only thing that still bugs me are the optional tombs, which could somehow be better connected to the game itself. They are just simple puzzles you do not have to do, but when climbing trough old ruins they could be a much bigger part of the game and help to continue the story. Leave the special upgrades in the graves, for explorers.

Lara improved, she is not a little man-slaughtering baby anymore that cries about everything. She has become a man-slaughtering woman, a goddess with the bow and she is really fond of it. Oliver Queen got nothing on her!

Definitly worth it. I demand the third installment now.

reviewText:
A pretty complete game, took me about 40hrs to complete to 100% (inclinding side quests and challenges) which is to me a pretty decent duration for a game of this quality. Graphics are outstanding in any environment, yet very demanding for the average user's pc (I have a beast of a pc so it wasn't an issue to me but I wish I could have played it on my laptop).

Still recommanding this game, though be mindful not to rush the main story and complete the side quests and challenges as soon as you can, they are really worth it as they complete the main quest and help you better understand the Lara Croft's background as a Tomb Raider! Also set the game difficulty to the 3rd or 4th level if you play on pc, this will add a bit more challenge (I guess the two first ones are meant for xbox and ps4 users as the AI are really easy to take down).

Overall really good experience, will not keep you busy as long as GS:GO but pretty enjoyable though!

reviewText:
Amazing. It has everything you want in an adventure game. It's very beautiful and you will get lost in the environments multiple times. There are tons of graphical features and customization options, even a spectator mode I can't imagine anybody would ever want to use. It's an amazing game, and instead of taking away action elements from the original they have expanded upon them and made them better. Nearly half of the game is now firefights, which is actually fun. You can now craft stuff which sounds boring but is simple and cool, alternate modes of firing use seperate ammunition, stealth is actually fun and often a viable option, upgrades are much more varied and complicated and the gameplay and puzzles are spot on. It's one of the best games ever made, period. The story is also really fun, and Lara has changed.

Do not buy if you can't get over the old Lara nobody apparently wants to buy.

Also, fancy hair that doesn't make your GPU slow as a snail? YES please.

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider is great sequel to it's predecessor, Tomb Raider.

First impressions -
Runs great, doesn't drop below 80fps with max settings on my pc:

-GeForce GTX 980

-Intel Core i7-4790 CPU 3.60GHz

-16.00 GB RAM

-Windows 10

Great gameplay that improves upon the previous game. Amazing crafting system that vastly improves and adds to what the original system had given us. The story, so far gives an intriguing and continuous story from the previous game. I recommend this game to anyone who has played the previous game and others who are new to the franchise. This is a solid pc port with great optimization and surprisingly works well with a mouse and keyboard.

column19: as well as the need to preserve certain items in order to make sure I would stay alive incombat. The stealth system also feels quite improved
column20: with there being more to it than just "shoot everyone in the head from afar".\n\nFinally
column21: the most important part of Tomb Raider is the "adventure" of it
column22: which does indeed exist in Rise of the Tomb Raider. Every area feels very fresh
column23: and all colored very vividly and beautifully
column24: and every moment where you are on the run actually feels like an action sequence
column25: rather than a five second QTE.\n\nOf course
column26: all of that doesn't mean to say that there aren't flaws to this game that existed in the previous. The enemies still know your location at every moment
column27: the game is still focused on telling a story rather than being a game
column28: many of the tombs in the game are still 100% optional
column29: and the ridiculous
column30: waste-of-time collectibles are still here. There's even a "language skill" that you improve by collecting some of those collectibles
column31: but even that just feels completely unnecessary. Alongside those collectibles is the collection of natural and man-made resources
column32: which may or may not hinder your enjoyment of the game
column33: seeing as those resources are mandatory to your "survival" throughout the game.\n\nAll-in-all
column34: it's quite easy to say that Rise of the Tomb Raider isn't a great game
column35: and probably isn't even the the best in its genre
column36: yet it manages to be a very complete one
column37: regardless of the somewhat-short length of 12-15 hours. It may not be perfect
column39: it has definitely "risen" out of its predecessor's mediocrity and become something of its own. It's a very enjoyable game
column40: and I recommend checking it out
column41: especially if you haven't played the original."

reviewText:
I played a few hours so far, but damn, this is so much fun. i have an older system, old i5@4.5gHZ, 16g. memory and a gtx 960, slightly overclocked. I'm running on medium setttings and no problems at all. However ..... it has crashed 3 times due to memory lock. Thhis uses ALOT of system resources. No big deal really ... other than that , graphics are amazing, game play is so much fun, its good to see the play mechanics are same as the previous game , no re-learning curve.  Price wise .. ummm haw .. its a toss up .. if i get enough play time for my $100, i bought the full digital pack, Then yes .. but so far i think its worth it.  if they bring out more content later , even better IF they bring it out within the season pass time.

All i can say, is don't balk at the steep price, its well worth it, no glitches, great fun,  its a well put together story line, great game play, great mechanics .. may need a bit of tweaking for your individual system, but hey.. thats why we build our own systems right?

Go for it .. you won't be sorry

Ps .. watch the youtube playthroughs .. you get an idea, but , BUT, they don't show the real graphics quality that you can get .. they really are fanominal

reviewText:
I'm seeing most negative reviews based on the fact of the day 1 discount and not being able to run it despite having a good PC for it.
day 1 discount I really have nothing to say about, because I waited to buy the game since I was broke up until it's release. I just got lucky with that, but that should never affect someone's review of the game.
As for performance the game has minor issues here and there, but I'm playing with most settings maxed out with a solid 60 FPS.
I'm playing an ASUS ROG laptop.
Nvidia GTX 970m graphics (3gig VRAM laptop card compared to the 4 gig desktop 970)
i7 4th gen 2.5 GHz processors
24 gigs of RAM

My build is less than other people who are complaining of serious performance issues, so all I can say is they must be doing something wrong. Maybe one of the more demanding options turned on that they don't need or something. It's a great game and runs really well. It plays smooth and really draws you into the element of trying to survive. So far things are well paced and the story is definitely keeping me hooked.

If you are getting persisting performance issues, turn some settings down. Some settings won't seem that significant but can make a HUGE performance impact.

I highly recommend this game to people who fans of the series or looking to get into a new sweet adventure game.

reviewText:
One of the greatest game ever... at least, for me.

Lara had a plastic surgery.

Bigger scale, bigger maps, bigger adventure and bigger story. Better things to do, enjoy, better outfits, better interfaces, better everything.
If u don't mind your wallet being empty (again), buy RoTR. Including DLCs.
Have some awsome experiences with it. Highly recommended for everyone.

reviewText: Great game so far, the graphics are excellent. The feel of the game is very similar to the previous one. One difference is that it is more demanding on your hardware. For example the area with the soviet base is very large and I would get framerates dropping to around 30 fps with an AMD R9 Fury X with all settings maxxed and SMAA at 1080p 144Hz. This was using the latest 16.11 crimson driver. I wasnt happy with this so I decided to rollback to driver version 15.11.1 and I gained about 20fps in almost every part of the game. Not sure whats different about the newest crimson driver, but it does impede performance quite a bit. Just something to consider if your using similar hardware.

reviewText:
A solid third-person-action game, but with little tomb raider identity and heavy performance issues.

Technical:
The game looks stunningly good and the background design is georgus. However, as soon as i translated to the wide open areas, big framerate drops occured. Especially in the valley during the stormy rain time. Im talking about going from solid 60-85fps down to 15-25fps. i played the game with a Strix GTX 970 stock clocked at 1080p. changing grahpic settings had little to no impact, even going from all topped out to medium, always got the same fps. Also, during the beautiful realistic setting and graphics, i suddenly encountered the worst looking avalanche...ever..in a video game, a animation, a movie...no idea who goofed this one up.

Gameplay:
Just as the first reboot title, it has good controls, nice climbing sections with diverse climbing mechanics, good gunplay but too much over-the-top-action sequences and so many collectibles, that is was most times just disctracing from the game.

What it does better from the precessor, is that they included 9 Optional Tombs with nice riddles. However, its only exactly 1 riddle per Tomb, completed in about 3-10 Minutes each. As if this wasn't dissapointing enough, Lara keeps talking, not just giving hints, but telling you almost exactly what you have to do, taking out every challange of the puzzles whatsoever

If the hole game was like this, than i would call it a great Tomb Raider game, but unfortunately the main story, is just a linear movie like third person action game. Thanks to the good diverse climbing and well done stealth passages, this game can somewhat hold up to the fanbase. If it weren't for those two things, this game would have gone the completly same route as modern Resident Evil titles, leaving all identity behind, going from a puzzle game to a action-movie like expirience.

The game features great weapon upgrade and customization system, as well hidden strongboxes, wich grant you different weapons models with different mechanics, like a full-auto-shotgun instead of a pump-action one.
The strongboxes are sometimes pretty obvious, and sometimes well hidden. As you progress, secrets are getting revealed on the map. Combined with the possiblities to fast travel back to earlier areas of the game, it is absolutely possible to get 100% collectibles in the game.
However, it's almost impossible to get every weapon upgrade in the game, as some parts are dropping off enemy soldiers. Some of them respawn, but it would take dozen of hours to get enough materials for alle the upgrades.
(I played on the hardest difficulty, wich makes upgrading require more parts)

However, there is one problem with the huge amount of collectibles. They are very distracting since there are so many. If you want to get them all, you will find yourself activiting the survival instinct mechanic every 5 steps, which got myself so annyoing, i wished there was nothing to find, so i don't get this flashy sound anymore.

Beside that, the over-the-top action in the games, was way too much. Starting from the first minute in the game, i kept aking myself how the hell would Lara survive that" ever 10 minutes. This game just trys way too hard to be entertaining like a michael bay movie.

Also
date:
this game features the most usless attack helicopter in history.

TL;DR:
A very solid third-person action game (7/10) with nice climbing
recommended: stealth and climbing mechanics.\nHeavy Technical issues in certain open areas (don't trust reviews that only feature the first hour of the Game)\nGreat voice acting
hoursPlayed: fluent diverse gameplay and cutscenes.\nStill lacks heavily of Tomb Raider identity
voteText: having only 9 greater Puzzles to solve. Fans of the original series will be dissapointed
helpfulPercent: as the new inclued "Tombs" are just an optional sidekick.\nBut still
votesHelpful: a very enjoyable single player game.\n\n..also
votesTotal: the worst
votesFunny: pathetic attack helicopter...ever"

reviewText:
Well if you enjoyed 2013 reboot of Tomb Raider you will enjoy this sequel.

Pro's:
-Really enjoyable.

-Beautiful world, great story-telling, and just a great experience to immerse yourself in and enjoy an adventure game.

-Plenty of time sink options (ie missions and collectables) in game and post game with mission style options.

-More tombs, more caves, more wild life enemies instead of always fighting humans.

-Pretty good performance on a 780Ti SC card.

Con's:
-Easy enemies, but it's fun. Something seems less fun about the combat from 2013 I'm not sure what it is.

-A few areas the frame rate just plummets. These are bigger areas and a ton of detail went into the world so it's tolerable.

-Forced back tracking to explore some areas and collect relics and weapons. Gear is acquired level by level, which opens tombs and crypts from previous levels which were unavailable due to missing gear.

-Short story. Not that short, but if you just play the game for the story without doing anything off the beaten path, I can guess this game can be completed under 15 hours. I have over 40 hours and I'm 50% roughly. It's worth taking your time.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
After throughoutly enjoying the previous reboot Tomb Raider (2013) I was really looking forward to Rise of the Tomb Raider for quite a while now - And it was well worth the wait!

Crystal Dynamics stepped up their game in the graphics department. The game looks absolutely stunning, especially in the cutscenes but also while normal gameplay. Thanks to motion capturing, insanely high end models and highres textures the characters look very lifelike and feel beyond real. The areas each have an unique feel to them and are very detailed. Only downside are the resulting fps, especially in some outside areas.

I also really enjoyed the story since it's solid, fun to follow and the characters feel authentic. Scattered around the map are countless letters and audiologs to find which tell tales of long gone individuals, like the man who chased the prophet. It felt very rewarding finding a new part of his story every now and then, since it also gives you more insight into the current storyline itself.

The gameplay recieved some upgrades as well, so it's even more fun to explore the relatively open maps, climb mountains, hunt for animal loot and decide for yourself which quests you want to do next. The game rewards you for exploring the area by finding weapon parts to unlock new weapons, single weapon accessories and so on. Gathering ressources enables you to modify weapons, improving their respective stats. By leveling up while playing and collecting stuff you can unlock skills which improve various general and weapon specific aspects of Lara, which is also rewarding.

The game offers at least 20 hours of gameplay without looking for all the collectibles. At this point I played it 25 hours and reached overall progress of 86%, so there are many more collectibles to find

I highly recommend Rise of the Tomb Raider. It's a must buy!

reviewText: The rebooted Tomb Raider series does not seem to disappoint. I was a huge fan of the first game where you get stranded on an island and you discover all of its secrets and you find weapons. Rise of the Tomb Raider is different with new weapons,outfits,map and a general storyline. The plot is very firm and everything is organized. The fighting is harder and I think the story is a bit longer than the first game. This series became one of my favorite series because it doesnt fail to bring you excitement and adventure.The game does not include multiplayer which might have been a nice addition with a different map but still loads of fun. The series sort of reminds me of the batman series which is probably my favorite series. Now the ending, is a cliffhanger which definitely implies a direct sequel. Some people may not like that because it makes people want to spend money but it was definitely a good way to end the game. Strongly Recommend if you really liked the first game.

reviewText: The first game already set the benchmark so high, and yet this sequel is able to top it. Less gruesome deaths for our lady protagonist (there is still some, and still just as cringe-worthy), really nice plot (while keeping it as realistic as possible), beautiful graphics, and Lara Croft's character development is nice. I like how the game is focused on puzzle-solving and exploration (which I personally enjoy in games), with some elements of stealth/shoot-em-down at certain points of the game. This variety of activities to do in-game prevents the game from getting too dull. The story's pace is nice, and the maps have many hidden caves and activities to do, living up to the name of Tomb Raider". Lastly

reviewText:
For sure, Rise of the Tomb Raider is able to impress more than the previous title. It's a great adventure, which is able to convey the feeling of loneliness and anxiety to survive in an environment completly free of any comfort and full of big treats.
All of this is surely about the excellent work done by the technical sector, which has made every details in the best ways, enabling the succes of the title.

First of all you have to admire the addictive Lara's expression, which is able to express every mood. Another point in favor is given to the movements, which can perfectly delineate every situation, it's a indoor climbing, a race in the midst of deep snow, or a gunfight. All this is surrounded by a scene worthy of note, with the shots that make perfectly the climate.
Almost all of the game concentrates in Siberia; the deep snow, the wind, the thick icy mountains generate an ambient that is at the boundary between game and reality, also the perfection of film shoots, giving a further touch of class.

The sequences less hectic are excellent too, especially the one linked to the Tomb. All the puzzles are designed in a very perfect way and they make the game free od monotony.
Unfortunately some flaw has to be assigned to the storyline, even it is to admit that improves compared to the previous title. The premises are very attractive; after the death of his father, Lara follows the footsteps of his father,she is looking for an ancient artifact that, according to legend, would give eternal life. Unfortunately, despite a dynamic and interesting start, the story gives way to the action part of the title. It is certain to say that if you don't like the first chapter, TR2013, perhaps you don't like this too, but in any case I think it is a great and funny adventure title.


Pro:

- Better story than the previous title, but not the best story ever

- Fantastic graphics, even better after the patch

- Excellent cinematic impact

- Excellent playability

- Big areas and true Tomb to raid

- Good crafting system

- Several levels of difficulty and challenge

Cons:

- The combat are not excellent

- Small difficulties using a mouse + keyboard in some places

reviewText:
A solid third-person-action game, but with little tomb raider identity and heavy performance issues.

Technical:
The game looks stunningly good and the background design is georgus. However, as soon as i translated to the wide open areas, big framerate drops occured. Especially in the valley during the stormy rain time. Im talking about going from solid 60-85fps down to 15-25fps. i played the game with a Strix GTX 970 stock clocked at 1080p. changing grahpic settings had little to no impact, even going from all topped out to medium, always got the same fps. Also, during the beautiful realistic setting and graphics, i suddenly encountered the worst looking avalanche...ever..in a video game, a animation, a movie...no idea who goofed this one up.

Gameplay:
Just as the first reboot title, it has good controls, nice climbing sections with diverse climbing mechanics, good gunplay but too much over-the-top-action sequences and so many collectibles, that is was most times just disctracing from the game.

What it does better from the precessor, is that they included 9 Optional Tombs with nice riddles. However, its only exactly 1 riddle per Tomb, completed in about 3-10 Minutes each. As if this wasn't dissapointing enough, Lara keeps talking, not just giving hints, but telling you almost exactly what you have to do, taking out every challange of the puzzles whatsoever

If the hole game was like this, than i would call it a great Tomb Raider game, but unfortunately the main story, is just a linear movie like third person action game. Thanks to the good diverse climbing and well done stealth passages, this game can somewhat hold up to the fanbase. If it weren't for those two things, this game would have gone the completly same route as modern Resident Evil titles, leaving all identity behind, going from a puzzle game to a action-movie like expirience.

The game features great weapon upgrade and customization system, as well hidden strongboxes, wich grant you different weapons models with different mechanics, like a full-auto-shotgun instead of a pump-action one.
The strongboxes are sometimes pretty obvious, and sometimes well hidden. As you progress, secrets are getting revealed on the map. Combined with the possiblities to fast travel back to earlier areas of the game, it is absolutely possible to get 100% collectibles in the game.
However, it's almost impossible to get every weapon upgrade in the game, as some parts are dropping off enemy soldiers. Some of them respawn, but it would take dozen of hours to get enough materials for alle the upgrades.
(I played on the hardest difficulty, wich makes upgrading require more parts)

However, there is one problem with the huge amount of collectibles. They are very distracting since there are so many. If you want to get them all, you will find yourself activiting the survival instinct mechanic every 5 steps, which got myself so annyoing, i wished there was nothing to find, so i don't get this flashy sound anymore.

Beside that, the over-the-top action in the games, was way too much. Starting from the first minute in the game, i kept aking myself how the hell would Lara survive that" ever 10 minutes. This game just trys way too hard to be entertaining like a michael bay movie.

Also
date:
this game features the most usless attack helicopter in history.

TL;DR:
A very solid third-person action game (7/10) with nice climbing
recommended: stealth and climbing mechanics.\nHeavy Technical issues in certain open areas (don't trust reviews that only feature the first hour of the Game)\nGreat voice acting
hoursPlayed: fluent diverse gameplay and cutscenes.\nStill lacks heavily of Tomb Raider identity

helpfulPercent: as the new inclued "Tombs" are just an optional sidekick.\nBut still
votesHelpful: a very enjoyable single player game.\n\n..also
votesTotal: the worst
votesFunny: pathetic attack helicopter...ever"

reviewText:
Mmm... yeah it's alright.

I've been putting off doing a review of this because I'm not sure what I can say about this game that I wasn't able to say about the first TR reboot. Lots of platforming and combat? Check. Collectibles? Check. Middling story? Check. Villains I wish I had killed but didn't? Check. Most of my deaths happening because the game didn't do what I was intending? Check. But honestly, it's fine. I didn't have any trouble running it, and the game itself is functional and competent, if perhaps somewhat unremarkable. reviewText:
After throughoutly enjoying the previous reboot Tomb Raider (2013) I was really looking forward to Rise of the Tomb Raider for quite a while now - And it was well worth the wait!

Crystal Dynamics stepped up their game in the graphics department. The game looks absolutely stunning, especially in the cutscenes but also while normal gameplay. Thanks to motion capturing, insanely high end models and highres textures the characters look very lifelike and feel beyond real. The areas each have an unique feel to them and are very detailed. Only downside are the resulting fps, especially in some outside areas.

I also really enjoyed the story since it's solid, fun to follow and the characters feel authentic. Scattered around the map are countless letters and audiologs to find which tell tales of long gone individuals, like the man who chased the prophet. It felt very rewarding finding a new part of his story every now and then, since it also gives you more insight into the current storyline itself.

The gameplay recieved some upgrades as well, so it's even more fun to explore the relatively open maps, climb mountains, hunt for animal loot and decide for yourself which quests you want to do next. The game rewards you for exploring the area by finding weapon parts to unlock new weapons, single weapon accessories and so on. Gathering ressources enables you to modify weapons, improving their respective stats. By leveling up while playing and collecting stuff you can unlock skills which improve various general and weapon specific aspects of Lara, which is also rewarding.

The game offers at least 20 hours of gameplay without looking for all the collectibles. At this point I played it 25 hours and reached overall progress of 86%, so there are many more collectibles to find

I highly recommend Rise of the Tomb Raider. It's a must buy!

reviewText: Improved on every single part from the original rebooted TombRaider, so if you liked the first one, you're def gonna enjoy this one. Great balance between action, exploring and Tomb Raiding. This is...a truly...a must play title.\nLot of ppl reported problems with frames droping, stuttering and even freezes on high-end computers. Sadly, I have to say that I had similar problems but nothing that extreme. Stuttering was fixes simply by lowering textures on HIGH (even tho i run two OverClocked 970s) and everything else on Very High. FPS drops where still present, especially on huge maps like Soviet Installation or Geotermal Valley, but it didn't stopped me from enjoying the hell out of game. Go. Now. Buy it.

reviewText:
Without a doubt one of the best games I've played in the past decade, easily belongs in my list of favourite games ever and it is a huge improvement over the 2013 Tomb Raider - which also was a enjoyable game.
Pretty much everything about this game screams production value:

-Absolutely top-of-the-line graphics, one of the best-looking games currently, if not THE best
-Gorgeous environments and vista's
-Lara controls fluidly and all animations are incredibly well-made with lots of eye for detail
-Very good gaming pace with adventuring, platforming, discovery/item hunt, action and setpiece-moments
-Story is passable but somewhat forgettable even though it has a purpose, the story is more led by the captivating experience of Lara's trials to rise to her legacy
-Great variety of locations, enemies and weapons aswell as a weapon upgrade and 'talent' upgrade system that give a sense of progression
-Combat is satisfying and can be dealt with in many ways (in most parts, pure stealth kills is easily a valid playstyle)
-One of the few games that does 'collecting/checklisting stuff' right, its fun without overdoing it and in no way required to beat the game or where it truly feels like a chore
-Nearly no quick-time events, in current day & age this is a welcome change
-I did not encounter serious bugs or graphical issues (ran fluidly on a GTX 970, maxed out) apart from one instance where an enemy soldier stood in T-pose

If I do have to create some cons:

-The 'main bad guy' is very forgettable and there is never really a sense of threat, there is no real sense of intimidation or angst towards him. I was more impressed with Baba Yaga instead of the main villain
-The ending to me was somewhat disappointing, for obvious reasons not going to explain why but it was a tad anti-climactic
-The game feels a bit too easy even when played on Survivor (which is the hardest mode)
-The season pass is very barebones for what you pay for: Baba Yaga (which is like 3 hours, 4 if you stretch it with 100% completion), a horde mode & a survival mode. I'd rather have them make more 'story' content than tacked-in survival or horde mode stuff which is, lets be honest, pretty boring in nearly every game and serves as pure filler for the pass.
Regardless I bought the season pass knowing what was in it to support the developers for creating this game but it really is not worth the money asked for - Baba Yaga is good but short and also the only content that really interests me

Regardless of the cons, this game is fantastic and should be played by anyone interested in the genre or the IP (scratch that, everyone should play this, period), this game brings the new standard and it will be immensely hard to be knocked off its throne.

reviewText:

reviewText:
Since I got this game for free, I don't know if this game is worth it's price, but what i do know is that this game is a good game. While there were almost no gameplay changes, the gameplay wasn't something that needed to be fixed, so it's not really a problem. Would I recommend this game to those of you who have lots of money laying around and have already played the first one? Yes, of course, this game is great go right for it.

Would i recommend this game to the budget gamers who don't want to shell out $60 for this game? No, I'd say to buy the game before this and play that as it still looks gorgeous and the such.

reviewText:
Great game if you've got the hardware to run it.
Up front Specs:
Sli 980's
i5-4690k @ 4.1Ghz
16 GB ddr 3 1866Mhz
W10
27 in Gysnc IPS @ 144Hz 1440p

Now thats out of the way, on performance for me I can say its got decent sli scaling (48fps on 1 card) (80fps on sli) not as good as TR2013 but decent and I'm sure it will improve with patches/driver optimization. I play at my native res of 1440p with no vysnc so framerates are uncapped and the above is just an average. All settings accept AA are maxed or enable (including Pure Hair ) .
So if you have a similar system thats a pretty good idea of what you can expect performance wise as of the posting of this reveiw.

GamePlay:
Similar to TR 2013 in that its action focused around big set pieces and intense up close interactions (like a Giant Grizzly popping out on you!)  It takes 2013's formula and pumps it up on steroids, better graphics. More intricate ruins/tombs to explore.  The crafting/upgrade system offers a ton more. Now instead of just  collecting scrap you will find actual resources, such as wood,berries,minerals,cloth and animal hides just to name a few. You can make different types of arrows, as well as upgrading your stuff. The collectables have a cool progression to them too, you will need to find artifacts releating to different ancient cultures to increase your proficieny in reading stuff (ie learning greek,mongolian etc) which helps to unlock the games more powerfull upgrades.  Laura's costumes come with different stat bonuses, giving you an excuse to wear a variety of them for more than just aesthetic value.

This game offers a real globe trotting feel compared to TR2013, which took place on one large island. In RotTR you will be zipping around to Syria, Siberia along with cutscenes that show life back in London. The main search is for some artifact that grants immortality, which was the undoing of Laura's father who was obsessed with the subject.  Very Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade like, but thats not bad imo you can have worse things to base you game plot around.

Controls:  Much like TR2013 controls are tight allowing for easy switching from ranged to melee in combat. This is enhanced by upgrades to have more melee or better shooting/bow skills.  There is a greater focus on allowing stealth gameplay which opens up how you attack a level.

Conclusion:
If you liked TR 2013 you will love RotTR because it follows the previous game's modis of operation, but it bigger, better and more intricate in just about every way. Just make sure you have the HW to run it first and take the time to find the right settings in the graphics menu that will be appropriate to your hardware.

reviewText:
For sure, Rise of the Tomb Raider is able to impress more than the previous title. It's a great adventure, which is able to convey the feeling of loneliness and anxiety to survive in an environment completly free of any comfort and full of big treats.
All of this is surely about the excellent work done by the technical sector, which has made every details in the best ways, enabling the succes of the title.

First of all you have to admire the addictive Lara's expression, which is able to express every mood. Another point in favor is given to the movements, which can perfectly delineate every situation, it's a indoor climbing, a race in the midst of deep snow, or a gunfight. All this is surrounded by a scene worthy of note, with the shots that make perfectly the climate.
Almost all of the game concentrates in Siberia; the deep snow, the wind, the thick icy mountains generate an ambient that is at the boundary between game and reality, also the perfection of film shoots, giving a further touch of class.

The sequences less hectic are excellent too, especially the one linked to the Tomb. All the puzzles are designed in a very perfect way and they make the game free od monotony.
Unfortunately some flaw has to be assigned to the storyline, even it is to admit that improves compared to the previous title. The premises are very attractive; after the death of his father, Lara follows the footsteps of his father,she is looking for an ancient artifact that, according to legend, would give eternal life. Unfortunately, despite a dynamic and interesting start, the story gives way to the action part of the title. It is certain to say that if you don't like the first chapter, TR2013, perhaps you don't like this too, but in any case I think it is a great and funny adventure title.


Pro:

- Better story than the previous title, but not the best story ever

- Fantastic graphics, even better after the patch

- Excellent cinematic impact

- Excellent playability

- Big areas and true Tomb to raid

- Good crafting system

- Several levels of difficulty and challenge

Cons:

- The combat are not excellent

- Small difficulties using a mouse + keyboard in some places

reviewText:
9/10

Must buy. There are some very minor flaws with this game but thankfully they are easily over looked.

Pros:

Story, interesting concept, plays like a film.
Graphics, excellent port, very little slow down, 40FPS on average with a 980Ti and i7 2600k @ 4.2GHz with 4K res.
Side objectives that aren't as tedious as you would expect, I usually avoid collecting things but coupled with the XP system it felt more rewarding in this game.
Combat was enjoyable, I especially liked the combo system which rewarded chained stealth kills / head shots etc.
Animation is very fluid.


Cons:

Weapon upgrade system seems pretty pointless, you WILL stick to your favourite weapon.
Outfit advantages are uneeded, I ended up sticking to one throughout the game.
Skill point system was interesting but the only reason I felt I needed to fill it out was to gain higher tiers of crafting ability.
Side characters introduced which you care little to nothing about.
They have changed Laras face from the last game.

reviewText:
Great game if you've got the hardware to run it.
Up front Specs:
Sli 980's
i5-4690k @ 4.1Ghz
16 GB ddr 3 1866Mhz
W10
27 in Gysnc IPS @ 144Hz 1440p

Now thats out of the way, on performance for me I can say its got decent sli scaling (48fps on 1 card) (80fps on sli) not as good as TR2013 but decent and I'm sure it will improve with patches/driver optimization. I play at my native res of 1440p with no vysnc so framerates are uncapped and the above is just an average. All settings accept AA are maxed or enable (including Pure Hair ) .
So if you have a similar system thats a pretty good idea of what you can expect performance wise as of the posting of this reveiw.

GamePlay:
Similar to TR 2013 in that its action focused around big set pieces and intense up close interactions (like a Giant Grizzly popping out on you!)  It takes 2013's formula and pumps it up on steroids, better graphics. More intricate ruins/tombs to explore.  The crafting/upgrade system offers a ton more. Now instead of just  collecting scrap you will find actual resources, such as wood,berries,minerals,cloth and animal hides just to name a few. You can make different types of arrows, as well as upgrading your stuff. The collectables have a cool progression to them too, you will need to find artifacts releating to different ancient cultures to increase your proficieny in reading stuff (ie learning greek,mongolian etc) which helps to unlock the games more powerfull upgrades.  Laura's costumes come with different stat bonuses, giving you an excuse to wear a variety of them for more than just aesthetic value.

This game offers a real globe trotting feel compared to TR2013, which took place on one large island. In RotTR you will be zipping around to Syria, Siberia along with cutscenes that show life back in London. The main search is for some artifact that grants immortality, which was the undoing of Laura's father who was obsessed with the subject.  Very Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade like, but thats not bad imo you can have worse things to base you game plot around.

Controls:  Much like TR2013 controls are tight allowing for easy switching from ranged to melee in combat. This is enhanced by upgrades to have more melee or better shooting/bow skills.  There is a greater focus on allowing stealth gameplay which opens up how you attack a level.

Conclusion:
If you liked TR 2013 you will love RotTR because it follows the previous game's modis of operation, but it bigger, better and more intricate in just about every way. Just make sure you have the HW to run it first and take the time to find the right settings in the graphics menu that will be appropriate to your hardware.

reviewText:
Well if you enjoyed 2013 reboot of Tomb Raider you will enjoy this sequel.

Pro's:
-Really enjoyable.

-Beautiful world, great story-telling, and just a great experience to immerse yourself in and enjoy an adventure game.

-Plenty of time sink options (ie missions and collectables) in game and post game with mission style options.

-More tombs, more caves, more wild life enemies instead of always fighting humans.

-Pretty good performance on a 780Ti SC card.

Con's:
-Easy enemies, but it's fun. Something seems less fun about the combat from 2013 I'm not sure what it is.

-A few areas the frame rate just plummets. These are bigger areas and a ton of detail went into the world so it's tolerable.

-Forced back tracking to explore some areas and collect relics and weapons. Gear is acquired level by level, which opens tombs and crypts from previous levels which were unavailable due to missing gear.

-Short story. Not that short, but if you just play the game for the story without doing anything off the beaten path, I can guess this game can be completed under 15 hours. I have over 40 hours and I'm 50% roughly. It's worth taking your time.

reviewText: The rebooted Tomb Raider series does not seem to disappoint. I was a huge fan of the first game where you get stranded on an island and you discover all of its secrets and you find weapons. Rise of the Tomb Raider is different with new weapons,outfits,map and a general storyline. The plot is very firm and everything is organized. The fighting is harder and I think the story is a bit longer than the first game. This series became one of my favorite series because it doesnt fail to bring you excitement and adventure.The game does not include multiplayer which might have been a nice addition with a different map but still loads of fun. The series sort of reminds me of the batman series which is probably my favorite series. Now the ending, is a cliffhanger which definitely implies a direct sequel. Some people may not like that because it makes people want to spend money but it was definitely a good way to end the game. Strongly Recommend if you really liked the first game.

reviewText:
Style and substance.

I have just finished the story and it took me 24 hours. I'd say that's good value for money, considering I got it free with my 970! I'm not sure it's something I would have risked paying full price for normally but after having experienced it, it would have been money well spent.

The game is gorgeous and I thought the story was great (although predictable), it kept me engrossed as it kept building momentum. Everything seemed on point! Combat was fun, weapon choice was varied and satisfyingly customisable. You can even change Lara's attire which I thought was good as I made little stories up about what she was wearing at the time, Puzzles and tomb raiding made me scratch my head a few times but I was able to solve them, so they are not too difficult.

Overall, I'd say if you have any interest in Tomb Raider or enjoy playing games like Uncharted, you should definitely pick this up. It starts off quite slow but it's worth seeing through.

reviewText:
Already One Of My Highlights 2K16[/h1]

I had high expectations when a release date for Rise of the Tomb Raider was announced. But of course I tried not to be hyped since the last years many games were overhyped - when you played them or saw actual gameplay footage they were just bad or not close to what trailers showed.
But this title just surprised me. First, I was overwhelmed by the graphics (I didnt play too many new AAA Titles the last year, but if you did, i guess you'll still find it pretty). Then I saw how big some of the areas are and again was surprised. Beautiful landscapes and if you look close enough, they are full with collectables. As you may want to know, I played the game on 100%, got all of the collectables. And I was never really bored by searching the map. Gameplay was really good - Mechanics worked well and control input felt natural. I don't want to spoil the mechanics, which are augmented during the game. It's hard to describe, but I really loved the experience I had playing this game.  The story however is ok, a little bit flat and predictable (No trash plot  though).

Conclusion
If you played Tomb Raider 2013, you'll love that game. Some things are similar, but Rise of the Tomb Raider is better in many ways. I highly recommend this game to everybody who enjoys adventures, singleplayer, nicely designed game worlds and collecting (Also recommend the game when you don't like the last aspect since you can play it without searching for all the little things and sidequesting). Hope to see more from this developer studio :)

reviewText: While I'd recommend this to fans of the Tomb Raider reboot from 2013 and to fans of action/adventure games in general, I think its predecessor is a much better game overall. The graphics have had a major upgrade (this is one of the best looking games currently available...it will definitely put your CPU & video card through their paces as the cutscenes seamlessly transition into gameplay sequences and massive, highly detailed set pieces fill your monitor with spectacle and wonder) and the gameplay has been tweaked and refined here and there, but the plot progression, writing, variety of locales and level design, character development, and general level of quality didn't quite live up to my expectations. It is a much denser game - there are more interactive environmental factors, the areas are larger (though not as numerous, which works against the game as the plot is constantly progressing forward while you’re revisiting many of the same areas), and you have more hunting and combat options at your disposal - but the pacing and the manner in which the plot and settings unfold are uneven and streamlined to a fault. The campaign is very short...while I completed it in 30 hours, I spent much of that time collecting optional items and going on side quests completely tangential to the main storyline. The story missions themselves can be finished in around 15 hours that pass very quickly. While this is not a flaw in and of itself, the story contained in that short time is very flat and predictable (with a particularly mediocre ending), filled with one-dimensional characters we're never given much reason to feel much of anything toward. Much more could've been done with Lara Croft's backstory in particular, as she has the potential to be a very strong character (which is crucial as there are far too few portrayals of complex female characters in videogames) but her motivation is generic and never truly explored beyond a few rather forced flashbacks.\n\nDon't get me wrong – I very much enjoyed playing this and plan on going back to revisit earlier sections with tools acquired later in the game to explore the world more thoroughly (Metroidvania style, much like the 2013 Tomb Raider). I just never felt as though this surpassed the original in any way apart from the graphical upgrades. Beneath its brilliant sheen lays an emptier, more uneven and less memorable experience by comparison; regardless, it's superior to many of its peers and a high quality title well worth playing, though I would recommend waiting for a sale (I was lucky enough to find a discounted pre-purchase). Also, don't expect to run this at higher settings unless you have a powerful PC, as it is one of the most graphic-intensive games currently available (at the very least, Lara Croft has the most graphic-intensive hair currently available)...it's just too bad that is its biggest improvement over its predecessor.

reviewText:
First and foremost, if you have not played the 2013 Tomb Raider reboot, absolutely go do that first, then consider if you want this.

I would dumb this down as a much more polished and refined version of the 2013 Tomb Raider. It generally relies on the same mechanics with new twists here and there, improved progression, more varied and more challenging combat etc. etc... The result is unsurprisngly a very good game, and if you have enjoyed the 2013 Tomb Raider, you will certainly enjoy this one even more. For your money you'll be getting around 35 hours of singleplayer gameplay for one complete playthrough, and then of course you can enjoy the multiplayer which is geared towards playing in a smaller group of friends. Over all I'd say the purchase is well worth it.

I'll elaborate on a few things below if you're interested:

PUZZLES: People say they're too easy. In my opinion, yes and no. They're not gonna send you looking for a youtube guide, that's for sure, but on the other hand, they're not gonna send you looking for a youtube guide. You're faced with solid, multi-stage puzzless you can solve yourself in 10-20 minutes and have all the sense of accomplishment for yourself. I rate that as a good thing, it's a nice middle ground. Although I would have preferred if these kinds were confined to the main story so as not to hinder progress where everyone has to go through them, and then the optional tombs should perhaps be a head scratcher.

THE WORLD: It isn't really open as is often said, it's handled the same way it was done in the previous game, a series of areas, some very big, some very small. But none that would take more than a couple minutes to traverse from side to side. There is of course collectibles and little climbing sequences and what have you scattered all about and I have actually much enjoyed doing them. part of this has to do with the fact that they're often blocked off until you acquire specific gear to access them by progressing the main story. I wasn't too sure about this, in the end deciding it's a good thing, since it forces you to do portions of scurrying about and doing missions, thus giving you a balnced portion of both, and preventing either from becoming mundane. The downside of course being that you have to come back to areas you've already been to multiple times.

THE STORY: Not much to be said about that, nothing stellar, but decent enough to keep you wanting to learn more, though the characters often lacked depth and unless you go through the trouble of collecting and reading the documents scattered around the world it might even feel a bit lackluster and bare bones. But seeing as I did, I have no real complaints.

THE SEQUEL: This to me is my biggest fear. RotTR was nodoubt a good game. But you could feel they were afraid to experiment. They polished and improved, carefully put in a new idea here and there, but all in all not that much has really changed. The Assassins Creed is an excellent comparison here. We've had AC 1, and now an AC 2, so let's hope to god the next TR game the devs will be allowed some creativity and we won't have an AC 3.

reviewText:
Very early performance and even lighter initial gameplay review all subject to change further in...Just wanted to give a review mainly on the performance for what would be considered a budget base gaming system like mine but gameplay wise it's as good as the last, need to play more to say whether or not it's better / bigger at this point.

My system spec is a GeForce GTX 750 Ti 2GB, 8GB Ram, AMD FX 4100 Quad-Core 3.6 GHz, Windows 10 Home (64Bit) @ 1920x1080p Borderless fullscreen (2 displays, 2nd is 1280x1024) using a Xbox 360 wired controller.

Performance is thankfully excellent in this game for me thus far (reached first Tomb at time of writing, performance may need tweaking when in action or more foliage dense locations) and the visuals, lighting, facial and lip-syncing are something to behold.

Settings-wise (like to give a shout-out to games like this that take the time to give some explanation to each setting and its purpose) I'm playing (non SSD) at 1080p with V Sync Triple Buffered, SMAA for antialiasing and all graphics settings at on (including Hair effects which isn't a system hog this time) / maximum aside from Textures which is on high (Very High is for Christ-like / 4K and 6GB+ cards although if you're to believe NVidia you need a Titan X with 16GB or other! 0_0).

Again this may need to be tweaked as I get to more active areas and environments and I have experienced minor stutter between gameplay & cinematic switches and the loading can be a little naughty but I accept these things knowing I'm pushing it with my spec already and especially with some of the odd performance horror stories going around so I have to be happy with the smooth framerate I'm getting thus far!

Gameplay stuff will be updated further in if I remember and can be ars*d to do so.

reviewText:
That old taste for adventure!
The emotion, the feeling of living a great adventure, discover wonderful places and lose yourself in them, the feeling of adrenaline in each jump, in each fall, look higher to see where to climb, the mere fact of enjoying the story without taking decision or whatever, simply discovering the history they have written... remember the feeling you had when you played those old games on your childhood? All those ancient flavours are present here. I feel like a kid playing this game, and is ♥♥♥♥ing great.

What a game!! The game is an improvement of all the things its predecesor had in every single way possible, so if you like the first one this will blow up your mind. Like the first one is more Lara Croft meets Sam Fisher in the wilderness. Lara feels more grown-up, the story is far more interesting and it's very well written (will catch you). The game is more dark and violent (even gruesome sometimes). Now the characters are really interesting too. nice exploration, in fact now exploring is really interesting because it rewards you with weapon upgrades, skills... a better narrative, bigger escenarios, puzzles, tombs (great ones and more well designed. The tombs are really big, you even forget that are optional), the combat is very fun and well made, better stealth moments (with specific skills), crafting (make ammo, new equipment, outfits, different stuff...), a lot of weapon (four different categories) with different stats and improvements, new skills, there are sidequest now, those missions reward you with special upgrades... and the game is visually astonishing. Evocative, amazing, beautiful and incredibly dynamic. Best action-adventure in a very long time.

As a final note, the character of Lara is amazing, strong, capable, determined and tenacious. Her evolution over previous game was amazing, and even more in this one. We need stronger and   REAL  women in video games, and not those stereotyped who always need a man to rescue them.

reviewText:
Rank: 8/10
Recommendation(s): Like action games, be able to handle a few minor QTEs, own a Maxwell GPU
Major Theme: Action game with leading graphics
Bought at Price: $69.99 (Pre-order)

I should probably address the pre-order situation. I'm not completely against pre-ordering, but when it comes to games like these, I certainly pre-order. Sure, I had thought about the game being a massive huge flop, but I was more than willing to take the risk with this game because of the previous game (2013).

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=610525783

I strongly support developers who take the time to ensure that their games work outstanding on the PC. That was the main reason why I pre-ordered.

This game certainly isn't for everyone, and if you didn't like Tomb Raider 2013, you might be able to enjoy this title a little more because of the reduced quick time events (QTE).

Rise of the Tomb Raider is an action game, in a third person view. The camera angles during cut scenes and swimming provide unique and interesting asspects on the ♥♥♥-ets in game (I mean aspects and assets, yes...).

While some won't like the actiony feel of the game, I always found that the stealth options to be my calling. The whole gun blazing way of playing the game doesn't really appeal to me. It would feel like you are making the game easy. Combine the stealth approaches with either the seasoned raider or survivor difficultly levels, and the game should be very appealing.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=610443306

The main story line isn't that challenging, but the optional tombs do provide relief towards the game feeling like a cake walk. I couldn't see myself playing with the difficulty set below seasoned raider.

One improvement from the 2013 game is that there are a lot more options as to customization and crafting. There are more items to craft, and more items used in crafting.

Another would be the very optional quests you can do. These would be familiar territory for any RPG players who are also looking to play Rise of the Tomb Raider.

While there isn't much for the simple plot and limited game play time (about 15 hours), the graphics are leading edge. I've told a lot of people that this title is clearly a milestone as to computer graphics. We are getting closer and closer to being able to have movie quality graphics rendered in real time. On my system with a GTX 980Ti, it was very obvious when there were sadly still a few pre-rendered video cut scenes.

For some reason, these pre-rendered cut scene videos were not even 60fps, but rather 30. No idea why that was, because a few of the scenes my system would have been more than capable of handling the rendering them.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=612452475

The main reasons you are going to end up playing Rise of the Tomb Raider are really going to be: you like the action of the latest Tomb Raider games, you like the graphics, and maybe you even enjoy Lara.

reviewText:
I am not sure but here is what I think so far...

This game has incredible graphics and I love the map itself . It's kind of an open world game , but still , is not a huge open world game , so dont expect a huge map which needs lots of hours to fully explore (In comparision to other maps)

There are some pretty interesting weapons starting from a bow , and then we got rifles and guns and they are also fully upgradable which is very good.

The storyline is not the best , but still It gets interesting and well , I like it so far. The secondary missions and sites are usefull for your items , you can get diffrent parts for your weapons from tombs and missions , so you should have a look at them , I personally love the puzzels in this game. But the bad part is that the puzzels are too easy , so yeah if you are thinking of hard puzzels that needs some good time of thinking , well those are not like that...they are easy puzzels.

Also the AI is too bad....Well I am playing on medium difficulty (Tomb Raider) and some of the enemyes cant see me if I stand in front of them (about 4 m) , also their shooting is weird , they shoot few bullets and then they stop and look at you and then they shoot few more bullets.(This is something that it's weird for me)

The parkour is inspired from games like Assassins Creed , well I like the parkour , is pretty nice , you can air assassinate tragets from trees that you climb , so this is a new thing that I like

You also have a skill tab where you upgrade your character.

But , I felt like I played a Tomb Raider (2013) which was a bit modified , then it had some better graphics , a diffrent story line , but with the same kind of subject / idea. You play as a girl , you must kill the enemyes which are set in diffrent camps , you explore caves and stuff , and the list goes on.

Anyway to sum up , yeah this game is not a bad game , but the thing is that the puzzels are too easy , the AI could have been a bit more smarter and stuff aaand I understand that this is like a Tomb Raider 2 , but still it is not something special and diffrent , sooo I am not very sure about this game , I am enjoying it but is not what I  expected , it could have been better tho....

reviewText:
Very early performance and even lighter initial gameplay review all subject to change further in...Just wanted to give a review mainly on the performance for what would be considered a budget base gaming system like mine but gameplay wise it's as good as the last, need to play more to say whether or not it's better / bigger at this point.

My system spec is a GeForce GTX 750 Ti 2GB, 8GB Ram, AMD FX 4100 Quad-Core 3.6 GHz, Windows 10 Home (64Bit) @ 1920x1080p Borderless fullscreen (2 displays, 2nd is 1280x1024) using a Xbox 360 wired controller.

Performance is thankfully excellent in this game for me thus far (reached first Tomb at time of writing, performance may need tweaking when in action or more foliage dense locations) and the visuals, lighting, facial and lip-syncing are something to behold.

Settings-wise (like to give a shout-out to games like this that take the time to give some explanation to each setting and its purpose) I'm playing (non SSD) at 1080p with V Sync Triple Buffered, SMAA for antialiasing and all graphics settings at on (including Hair effects which isn't a system hog this time) / maximum aside from Textures which is on high (Very High is for Christ-like / 4K and 6GB+ cards although if you're to believe NVidia you need a Titan X with 16GB or other! 0_0).

Again this may need to be tweaked as I get to more active areas and environments and I have experienced minor stutter between gameplay & cinematic switches and the loading can be a little naughty but I accept these things knowing I'm pushing it with my spec already and especially with some of the odd performance horror stories going around so I have to be happy with the smooth framerate I'm getting thus far!

Gameplay stuff will be updated further in if I remember and can be ars*d to do so.

reviewText:
Rank: 8/10
Recommendation(s): Like action games, be able to handle a few minor QTEs, own a Maxwell GPU
Major Theme: Action game with leading graphics
Bought at Price: $69.99 (Pre-order)

I should probably address the pre-order situation. I'm not completely against pre-ordering, but when it comes to games like these, I certainly pre-order. Sure, I had thought about the game being a massive huge flop, but I was more than willing to take the risk with this game because of the previous game (2013).

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=610525783

I strongly support developers who take the time to ensure that their games work outstanding on the PC. That was the main reason why I pre-ordered.

This game certainly isn't for everyone, and if you didn't like Tomb Raider 2013, you might be able to enjoy this title a little more because of the reduced quick time events (QTE).

Rise of the Tomb Raider is an action game, in a third person view. The camera angles during cut scenes and swimming provide unique and interesting asspects on the ♥♥♥-ets in game (I mean aspects and assets, yes...).

While some won't like the actiony feel of the game, I always found that the stealth options to be my calling. The whole gun blazing way of playing the game doesn't really appeal to me. It would feel like you are making the game easy. Combine the stealth approaches with either the seasoned raider or survivor difficultly levels, and the game should be very appealing.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=610443306

The main story line isn't that challenging, but the optional tombs do provide relief towards the game feeling like a cake walk. I couldn't see myself playing with the difficulty set below seasoned raider.

One improvement from the 2013 game is that there are a lot more options as to customization and crafting. There are more items to craft, and more items used in crafting.

Another would be the very optional quests you can do. These would be familiar territory for any RPG players who are also looking to play Rise of the Tomb Raider.

While there isn't much for the simple plot and limited game play time (about 15 hours), the graphics are leading edge. I've told a lot of people that this title is clearly a milestone as to computer graphics. We are getting closer and closer to being able to have movie quality graphics rendered in real time. On my system with a GTX 980Ti, it was very obvious when there were sadly still a few pre-rendered video cut scenes.

For some reason, these pre-rendered cut scene videos were not even 60fps, but rather 30. No idea why that was, because a few of the scenes my system would have been more than capable of handling the rendering them.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=612452475

The main reasons you are going to end up playing Rise of the Tomb Raider are really going to be: you like the action of the latest Tomb Raider games, you like the graphics, and maybe you even enjoy Lara.

reviewText:
This game seriously feels like just going through the motions.  Where the caves of the first game had you actually thinking about where to cling on to, this one feels like a walking simulator..... grappling walls are perfectly placed,  There is always a climbing board right where you need it, and why the heck are there so many gadgets.....

There are a few side missions in the game, but they are laughable.... There is one part where you have to carry supplies to a lower part of the map, then instructed to return to the upper part of the map to get more, then back to the lower, then once again back to the upper to turn in the quest..... I almost threw up at how padded that was designed...

The first one's story was really intense and interesting, but this one it feels so pointeless and selfish.... really wish I wasnt so disappointed in this game... The story does pick up and the last 2 hours are really fun, but you have to go through 10 hours just to get interesting.....   I wanted to like this game really badly but there arent a lot of redeeming factors for me.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Visually stunning graphics
- Decent storyline, despite being very cliché
- Gameplay is a lot smoother and fluid than its predecessor with less glitches and such. ROTR brings back a lot from the first game such as the action packed escapes & many of the old weapons but introduces a lot of new elements such as a lot more weapon/skill upgrades and a new focus on material collecting for crafting equipment
- Level designs are large and detailed, lots to explore in each one

Cons:
- The game becomes quite repetitive as you get into it, almost feels like the game cycles between running and killing enemies
- Seems like there is a larger focus on combat and killing than exploration. For a Tomb Raider game I would've liked to seen a focus on puzzle solving

8.5/10. Overall a pretty solid and well designed game, but definitely not better than the first one. Hopefully the next sequel will be!

reviewText:
Absolutly an AMAZING game! The graphics are beuatiful and realistic! I only dropped below 60fps on loading screens. running hihest settings. I have a i7 47k gtx980ti 32gb ram and some other goodies on board but still this game is stunning. The story line is rather short for a 60$ game but it is packed full of action and parkour challenges. I have completed this game on tomb raided difficulty and I must say it wasnt easy and was perfectly balanced for my stlye of play. If you are unsure about buying this game for full price. Dont be cause its 10% off lol. But for real even if you want to wait for it to drop below 30$ YOU HAVE TO PLAY THIS GAME!

Wondering what games its like? Well its a tomb raider so you are going to be searching caverns and old dig sites. But it has parkour simialar to dying light(also a great game). Late game feels a little like assasins creed with all the special abilities going around performing stealth takedowns. Has the guns down pat. Its got csgo quallity of shooting, with added features of course. Honestly if they made this game multiplayer with its mechanics it would be 10000x the recently call of duties. However there are some non-gamebreaking bugs such as shaking cut scenes and teleporting through walls. A little slugish system for the parkour mechanics at times, as it tries its best to go where your mouse is,

Overall I r8 8/8 Would r8 again m8. But for real 10000/10 game I cant wait for the dlc as they leave you on a good foot is all im going to say :)

reviewText:
I absolutely loved the previous Tomb Raider game, my only problem with it was the excessive use of QTEs.

PROS:

- QTEs are minimal and only really used when grabbing onto ledges and such.

- Graphics are beautiful, maxed the game out and it runs flawlessly.

- Sound quality is amazing from music to ambient effects to voice acting.

- Story is good so far, though I'm not too far in yet.

CONS:

- The microtransaction stuff is a bit strange but you can ignore it for the most part.

- The sale right after release is a bit of a ♥♥♥♥ move but it doesn't stop the game from being great.

9/10 so far since the cons are minimal and don't impact the game at all.

reviewText:
I would recommend this game to everyone out there looking for an open world and an adventurous experience that you can get by playing The Rise of the Tomb Raider. Honestly, the game itself Tomb Raider has been out for soo long with multiple sequels, but if anyone of you who love playing Tomb Raider like I do, would highly recommend it because of it's graphics performance as well as you get over 60FPS while playing it on ultra resolution (Depending on PC and Graphics Card). I really enjoy the story behind it, the challenges that you have to go through, there are multiple puzzles to solve and a lot more. I would also recommend buying a season pass for this game since you get extra modes and an expansion to the gameplay which is really interesting. But the only thing about the season pass is that you get outfits for Lara that you can already craft in the game. So, instead of purchasing the entire season pass, I'd recommend getting the expansion or the endurance mode.

Purchasing this game was a satisfaction for me since I really love playing Tomb Raider, but you'll enjoy the most out of this game by, high resolution gameplay, challenges that Lara goes through and a really interesting story of the game as well.

Would definitely give it a 10/10. Happy Gaming :)

reviewText:
You won't regret this purchase! I admit I've never been a huge fan of tomb raider games. I'm not heavily into the story of them and I disliked the game before this one.

From the second the game started, I was hooked. The opening sequence and movements felt right. The story has progressed smoothly and fluently. Not divulging too much or too little information. I'm intrigued with the history so far and it has given me that feeling that you never want the game to end. I want to stay up all night and explore every crevice and object.

Graphics are beautiful and I don't get bothered by the camera changes. Sometimes things like that can turn a great scene into an annoyance. The combat has been fun and so has the gathering. I'm not yet tired of scoping out new animals to scavenge from. I like the levelling up system and crafting. All in all, I think this is well worth the buy and I will be recommending to my fellow adventurers.

reviewText:
Thank you Crystal Dynamics for bringing back the tombs full of puzzles!

Rise of the Tomb Raider is the sequel to the 2013 reboot of Tomb Raider and it surpasses the original in nearly every way.  First are the visuals, which at times, even on high settings, can be breath taking.

The gameplay is smooth and the combat is fierce and quick.  Lara has many weapons at her disposal to dispach her foes; from a bow and arrow, to homemade grenades to an assortment of pistols, rifles and even a shotgun or two.  All of which are upgradable to deal extra damage, have a faster fire rate, or be more accurate.

Action sequences are brutal and intense.  Enemies attempt to outflank the player while a team member provides covering fire, pinning the player down.  Lara is able to use stealth to overcome many enemies, but can also craft homemade grenades, molotovs and smoke bombs when the right items are nearby.

The sounds are well produced with each weapon having a different report that lends accuracy and immersion to the game. Voicework is well acted, albeit unrealistic with virtually an entirly American sounding cast for many Russian, Greek and other voiced characters.

Mostly, Im pleased with the new tombs.  They are very nicely done, giving the player simple, yet vast puzzles to solve through each tomb.  This was sadly underdone in the 2013 reboot and its a welcome addition to this sequel.

The game runs well for my modest AMD system, though some users are reporting studdering and frame drops.  Once a patch (or new drivers) are released the game should be near flawless.

High recommendations, but not perfect due to some voicework and some techinical issues.
8/10 Overall, fix the techinal issues and its a solid 9.
Jan 31, 2016
