reviewText:
Great port of a great game. I played through it on Xbox One and loved every second of it. HOWEVER, the PC version blows that version out of the water (assuming you have decent hardware).

I can't get over how amazing it looks.

It is definitely worth your time. It improves upon the fantastic formula from the previous game and adds some fun stuff to do on the side. The only downside is that there is no multiplayer. I rather enjoyed that in the previous one. There is a lot of value in this product. Even at full price it's worth every penny.

TLDR: Just add it to your cart and buy it. Think about the consequences of your financial decisions after you play it. Cast aside all cares and just pull out that wallet. Make mommy proud.

reviewText:
As Among Thieves was to Drake's Fortune, so this game is to the rebooted Tomb Raider.

There are just so many small things that I love about this game that, when put together, create a fantastic game. Perhaps my personal favorite is the introduction of resources and the crafting of crucial components, from a larger backpack to poison arrows to bring down a bear to weapon upgrades. I really disliked that hunting in the first game was useful for a grand total of maybe 20 minutes and then tossed aside, but this time they outdid themselves. Hunting anything from deer to bears to birds and rabbits is useful, and hides are in high demand. It also doesn't feel like a chore, but is actually a fun mechanic in the game. Resources are abundant if you are vigilant enough (and not just heedlessly sprinting through the game), and hunting is easy if you are patient enough to use a vantage point to snipe an unaware buck.

Combat is more or less the same as the first Tomb Raider. You really don't want to end up in melee combat, but you do have the dodge counter available through skills, which can be quite useful. The ability to craft molotovs is extremely useful, as you can snipe somebody from a safe distance by grabbing a random whiskey bottle, lighting it on fire, and tossing it at him. The heal mechanic is incredibly nice, especially on the upper difficulties where there is no in-combat regen, as it allows you to manually heal yourself instead of relying on the *I just got shot, let me sit here for 5 seconds and pretend like nothing happened* method. It's still prudent to stealthily take out enemies, as Lara can be fairly easily overwhelmed.

I can't put my finger on specifically why, but I like the collectibles (including tombs) in this game quite a bit more than the predecessor. For one thing, there are a bazillion of them, but they also seem to make more sense. The challenges for sure are better, while the tomb puzzles are fairly simple to solve, but also quite rewarding as you get a new skill for completing each tomb that is extremely useful (e.g. survival instincts will show trap placements). There are also coins that can be exchanged at a merchant (damn Russian sellout just wants his vodka), but anything that is worth purchasing is extremely expensive, even if you manage to get all of the coin caches as each cache has 7 coins and the important stuff costs around 150.

So far the story has been a lot better in this game. We get to learn about Lara's relationship with her father and what drives her in her quest for the Divine Source. The supporting cast of characters actually feel somewhat fleshed out, but they never overshadow Lara. This is, first and foremost, a game about Lara Croft (which the first game seemed to emphasize to the point of excluding any character development for the other characters), but you can actually come to understand both the villains and your allies.

I seem to keep talking about this point despite claiming to put no stock in it as far as making or breaking a game, but the graphics in this game are just fantastic. Just watch Lara, whether in a cinematic or during actual gameplay. Her face shows so much emotion, her outfit glistens with snow or water depending on the weather conditions, her hair is detailed down to individual strands of hair. This game really is a pleasure to just look at, even though it definitely feels like they removed a lot of the sex appeal shots for Lara (she actually wears several layers while trudging through the snow covered mountains of Siberia... Who would have ever guessed?)

A small thing that I am not entirely happy about is that the game still has some feaux linearity in the form of campfire fast travel. It feels like the game would go wonderfully with an open world scheme a la Far Cry 3, but it's still a great deal better than the Uncharted series as far as linearity is concerned.

A side note outside of the game itself: I preordered the game, and as soon as it released, the price dropped by 10% for more or less the same content, and this Endurance mode, which sounds like something that should be released with the game, is instead $10 DLC. I wanted to support the developer by preordering the game, as i know that their sales have not been great despite the original game being fantastic as well as reviews for the Xbone version being high, but I feel like i was punished for doing so. I would advise against pre ordering, and just purchasing it on day 1. Even the pre-loading benefit was not much as it took about an hour to unpack after launch.

Overall, this game has far exceeded my expectations. Tomb Raider was already a very solid game, but the improvements in this game have put it over that edge from a fun, solid game to a must play experience for me. I give this game a 9.5/10, and look forward to Crystal Dynamics' next game.

reviewText:
The second installment in the amazing, rebooted Tomb Raider franchise. Lara is now in search of the Divine Source, the relic of immortality, as is the illuminati-like group Trinity. The game is very similar in mechanics and playstyle, being a linear driven story with open world exploration with an almost absurd amount of collectibles, however being Tomb Raider that is part of the fun, exploring.

The combat is extremely similar with a new mechanic being introduced, the on the fly crafting and resource gathering for offensive and healing purposes. The similarities are not only in the gameplay and combat, but also in the tombs and puzzles, the only difference being the puzzles seem to have gotten easier to a point where figuring this optional tombs puzzle is as simple as shooting a rope arrow and turning a crank, congrats! you figured out how to use the controls.

The downsides being the overly simplified puzzles and the DLC is not great, an hr long story DLC, and two challenge  modes that arn't particular spectacular.

Overall the game is amazing, fun gameplay and exploration, amazing combat finishers and the return of the brutal Lara deaths. Extremely cinematic with amazing visuals and extremely fun running sequences where everything is falling apart as you leap from crumbling collums to a swinging peice of scaffolding to land onto a cable, only after sustaining wounds that would kill any normal human, as Lara does. 9/10.

reviewText:
This game is awesome, but it isn't perfect. Ill be making a list of pros and cons and then finally give it a rating.

Pros:
-Awesome parkour
-Dense map
-Finding weapon parts is fun usually
-There are good graphics enhancers for those who dont like the washed out look (I used one and personally it made the game feel much more alive)
-The crafting and looting system is relatively good
-The plot is somewhat interesting but not enough to make me feel emotionally attached
-It isn't trying to replicate another games mechanics (in terms of parkour)
-animations look bloody awesome
-weather affects characters attire (snow can get caught in her hair and fall on her clothes)
-Mouse and keyboard are well mapped

Cons:
-Game seems short lived even after taking time to listen to audio tapes and watch cutscenes etc
-Map is small
-Side missions didnt give me any motivation after finishing the main story
-The story missions arent long enough for you to unlock everything while focusing on it.
-many outfits so little time
-Poor optimization (but bearable unlike ac unity)
-Without reshading this game lacks effects and a nice color palet. its also somewhat more blurry
-This doesnt apply to everyone but in the sequel I'd like the game to be more open and long with a more gripping plot and add more character development (crafting new tools, more unique weapons, side quests that dont apply to the main story or anyone related to the group/village.) But by far what I needed the most is a bigger map with areas of different climates (Id love to go back to Syria and explore more do more missions etc)4

Overall I rate this game 8.5/10
Id buy this game when its on sale unless you really want to play it

reviewText:
A nice balance of gameplay, story, and collection. I liked Tomb Raider 2013 and praised both the smoothness of the character's movement through the game and how, while there was much to collect, it isn't overly burdensome for completionists. Yes, I do use guides for a few hard-to-find pieces (my rule of thumb is when it's not fun, break out the Gamefaqs or IGN guides...), but you can get most things yourself with a little extra effort, and it's not a complete pain in the butt.

Rise of the Tomb Raider just smoothed out the rough edges from 2013. So, if you like 2013, you're going to find more to like in Rise. They also toned down the death animations (there's less torture-porn, as I call it), and really let Lara into her own.

I'm also a sucker for the outfit changes (some functional variations, yes, but mostly aesthetics and immersion), and I was pleased to see that there was virtually no fan-service. Yes, her butt looks good in everything, but there's nothing overly showy or sexualized, which is always nice to see with female game characters. Everything else, however, was absolutely eye-candy. Roaming the map was simply beautiful, and the fluid animation of character movement was a joy.

Whole-hearted recommendation from me.

reviewText:
One of my Top 10 Games, of all time
I cannot recommend Rise of Tomb Raider enough, the previous Tomb Raider (2013) was amazing, and was hard to beat. But this game just smashes it. The only reason I bought Rise of Tomb Raider was because I loved Tomb Raider so much.

I managed to 100% complete it, in just under 24 hours total. A very good, decent amount of time. This was only 1 play through, as I will probably play it again but on the hardest difficulty.

The look and graphics of this game are gorgeous and stunning, one of the best. The detail is really good of all objects, characters, animals and terrain. Looks life-like. The sounds, music and lighting are what makes it an aswesome game too.

The story, again was really good. Somehow better than Tomb Raider (2013)'s, and I like how we have a returning character from the previous game too. There some really emotional moments too, which are shown greatly in all characters.

The best thing I love about this game is the world map size, there are several differet regions that are all unique in some way, and there are hundreds of collectibles to discover, which some rerqure set skills and patience (which I like).

This game has set an extrealy high standard for Tomb Raider games, so the next one has alot to compete with. Especially if they want to make it (somehow) evern better.

Go buy this game, wether in a sale or not. And go buy Tomb Radier (2013) too!

12/10 - Lara's more hot (also dat ♥♥♥)

reviewText:
Completed this game in 22 hours. I guess it's a good gameplay time even I completed 75% of game (Skipped some tombs because of never ending curiosity what comes next).

You know, difference between Tomb Raider and Rise of Lara, In this game I never felt bored. I liked the world, I liked the mini-puzzles in tombs, I wanted to complete this game to see the final of this story. I like how emotional the beginning was, liked the introduction of characters, flashbacks, liked optimization from xbox (some games have such lame optimization @ start, = lags/fatals/etc). I liked everything.

For a fan, who completed all games (except the latest platformer Tomb of Osiris) from 1-st game to the last. I name this game one of the best if not the best game in the series.

Story was good, characters were emotional and I believed in their emotions, good work to voice actors and animation team. Music was well-fitted.

Only one thing made me sad.
When you had no arrows IT WAS HARD TO SHOOT ROPES sometimes (because of camera la. But, well, sometimes :D

Play on Survival Difficulty and have fun!
Can't wait for the next game.

reviewText:
I give 8 out of 10 for Rise of the Tomb Raider so far. (75% completion for finishing the main story)

For a game that released in 2016. (xbox one on late 2015) Graphic looks decent and runing around 25-30 FPS on med high setting on my 5 years old desktop. Gameplay itself has several improvment over the the predecessor. I didnt find an major bug during the gameplay.

Challenge mode is one of the biggest improvment and complete optional during the main story and it involved some basic puzzle solving  which takes a little bit of time to figure out. (otherwise the game feel like thrid person shooter) Side quest is a bit boring due to its game mode (either kill or get something) but it gives u some reward other than coins or resources.

Landscapes stick with snowmountains, deep undergournd ruins and villages in Siberia for 90% of the game. Desert and oasis in Syria appear in the second chapter which only takes no more than 30 mins gameplay. Sad thing is the predecessor already has too much snow and i personal seek different environment. But the good part is the game has large amount of scret tomb location (include challenge mode) compare to the predecessor, and it actually gives u bonus such as weapon parts or skills instead of just exploring.

I assume the game will take between 15 to 25 hours depend on ur play style. I played under survival difficulty and complete all challenge mode on the way through. Might take 30 hours or more to collect all the relic and other stuff.

Overall the game is decent, and much like the first Tomb Raider reboot, with few enhancement. Especially the Challenge mode makes the game more like a Tomb Raider" after all."

reviewText:
It's another Tomb Raider. Quite similar to the 2013 release gameplay-wise. If you loved it then, you'll love it again.

Pros:
+ a couple of original tombs to discover
+ great start
+ fun bow/arrow gameplay
+ a few very cool puzzles
+ some great locations
+ exploring
+ a bit Uncharted feeling
+ a few boss fights, that require a tad bit of strategy
+ DLC: Baba Yaga, Temple of the Witch is a cool and a bit different DLC. Has some exploring, puzzling, collecting and IMO the most interesting boss fight. Adds maybe an hour tops.

Cons:
- dull, predictable story
- some forced Call of Duty style passages
- mediocre skills, quite some useless in it (dodge kill)
- the landscape is not very diverse. Usually it's snowy and dark, sadly they didn't make much of the level in Syria
- general gunfights are tedious and not much fun. Enemies are boring

If you're new to the restarted franchise, I'd recommend picking up the 2013 version and play that first. It introduces Lara Croft and the whole franchise and has a bit more diverse level set. And it's much cheaper.

Story is really not much to speak of, especially if you played Indiana Jones, Uncharted and the likes.

Still, it's a solid game.

reviewText:
It's nice to see that the themes and artistic styles have continued in this latest version. The same niggles are still there such as occasionally patchy collision detection when making an awkward jump, and the constant respawning of wolves after you kill them 30 times as you run past an arbitrary point but that is more of a mechanic in games in general I think.

Overall, very pleased with it and am only 20% through the game (like taking my time to look around). Graphics are excellent as hoped for. Much was made of the hair tech and the difference between lara and the rather solid NPCs is evident. Perhaps in future versions the tech will be optimised to run on more than one character (at least it appears that way to me).

Gameplay is largely unchanged so far but have yet to come across many boss fight scenarios. The '3 times' rule where you effectively had to beat the boss 3 times using some stupid combination has hopefully been dropped but i will no doubt find that out at a later point in the game. Liking the crafting and would be nice to be able to get things like rope arrows earlier but hey, can't have everything!

reviewText:
If you liked the last Tomb Raider, you will most likely enjoy this.

+ Lara's character is a bit more developed here than the last game
+ Tombs are fun to explore, and satisfying to complete
+ Excellent visuals, with many options to tweak.. prepare to take many screenshots
+ Lots of environmental interaction (snow, wetness, dirt) and little details to add to immersion
+ Best hair physics ever

- Too much gunplay, not enough crazy complicated tombs.
- Certain areas of the game are significantly larger than others, causing framerate drops
- Survival senses and Lara's words can easily point you to tomb solutions, taking out some of the fun in solving it yourself

Overal this is an excellent adventure game, and I had a lot of fun with it. 9/10

reviewText:
Having played the 2013 Tomb Raider game just a couple months before I was pretty excited for Rise Of The Tomb Raider. It certainly didn't let me down the graphics visually are stunning in my opinion, they have kept lots of the survival elements, and the siberian mountains (wilderness) setting is perfect. The storyline is packed with action and adventure and theres nothing more satisfying than a long range headshot with the bow and arrow. It has a very simple and easy upgrade system and provides lots of interesting challenge tombs and interesting side missions which give you bonus such as lockpicking.

So if you're looking for an action/adventure with survival and crafting elements, and enjoy stunning visuals in the heart of the siberian wilderness then this game is for you! Also made by square enix so I guess they are doing something right!

9.5/10 - Visions

reviewText:
Rise is one of those games that you know you will enjoy if you liked the first game in the rebooted Tomb Raider series. This time the graphics have been improved to the point that I can safely say that Rise is the nicest looking game that I have ever played, it's not only the environments, it's the facial animations and expressions that Lara emotes throughout the game. Faces and emotional expressions have always given emotionally driven video game characters issues but CD really nailed it this time, Lara looks like a person and it's amazing to see in motion.

The game play imho has been improved quite a bit since the first game: combat is smoother and using stealth to attack entire groups is now much more intuitive and rewarding. Gunplay is improved with better overal handling of weapons and the addition of several types of weapons per class brings a lot of needed variety.

If you're expecting the game to be more than 50% tombs you're unfortunately going to be disappointed. There's a lot more raiding of ancient tombs/caves in this second game but a lot of them aren't nesassary to explore at all to finish the main story line and if you're a fan of some of the older TR games you may find the ones with puzzles to be a bit easy. With that said, there's a lot of exploring to do both in and out of the main plot and plenty of ancient artifacts to collect on your way throug the game.

If you get a bit tired of the main plot there's several options to pass the time outside of your saves, you have four replay modes which allow you to go back to completed chapters and get high scores to earn credits for cards and compete with your friends for the best scores. My favorite mode is Endurance mode which isn't included in the base game but it's available in the season pass and as a separate dlc for $9.99. Endurance is really self explanatory, you get dropped off at a location where you will need to hunt for food, keep your body warm, ward off enemies and explore ganerated tombs that are full of traps. If you die that's it, it's game over and you'll have to start again... this mode is extremely addicting and you can go a single session as long or as little as you'd like. If you don't want the season pass and the Baba Yaga dlc doesn't sound interesting to you, I highly recommend this mode.

As a side note, the extra outfits that are being sold as DLC can be crafted in the game if you don't have the season pass, you won't get the additional card packs for the replay and Endurance modes but if you don't care about those then save yourself some money and just craft them.

This game is hardware resource heavy and to enjoy maximum details you're going to need a modern and very beefy system.  My current hardware is a 3.5 ghz Xeon 1246 V3 with 32GB ram and a GTX 970 with settings maxed out I average 20 fps in some places, the lowest I get in other games at max settings  is 80 - 90 so it was a bit of a shock to see my system slow to a crawl like that. For Win10 users, DX12 support has recently been added in and for nvidia customers an exclusive Ambient Occlusion mode has been added in as another AO option that so far looks to be the most accurate I've ever used in a game.

I definitely recommend Rise to anyone who's a fan of the new reboot franchise, I've already put in 70+ hours into this game and I'm not even close to not being amazed.

reviewText:
I played the 2013 Tomb Raider reboot and it was amazing. I've been a Tomb Raider fan for a long time, puzzle solving games are especially my favorite. I was, in all honesty, super ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that I had to wait for this game to come out on PC, but in the end is was worth the wait. Here is my pros/cons list of the 2015 Rise of the Tomb Raider:

Pros:
1) The story is smooth. Really great character development
2) Replay value is high. You can just flow through the story and then do all that extra things (finding all the relics/etc) after
3) Amazing Graphics

Cons
1) I've had some glitches during combat (the enemy will just dissapear)
2) The puzzles are easier than the previous game (There's even a skill that lets you see what the challenges for that zone are)
3) The whole content of the game feels less than the previous title

Other than that, the game is really great. I'm only roughly 4 hours in and I can already tell I'm going to 100% this one, as I did with the last one.

Overall score:
8/10

reviewText: the ''sequel'' to Tomb Raider 2013 ( because this is Lara's first tomb raid, so not exactly a sequel but... ) is as good or even better than Tomb Raider 2013. The gameplay is relatively the same, which is not a bad thing since it already was really great, and in ROTTR they've added new movements and abilities to this already great gameplay. Graphics wise.... it's jaw-dropping, this game looks so good ( maxed out atleist ), it's the best graphics i've ever seen in a video game and it runs great ( apart from the texture quality settings, if you have anything less than 4 Gb of VRam, don't bother going ''very high'' you'll stutter ) and there's a lot of options here as well. Story now, it's great. I mean, it's Lara's first Tomb, following her dad's footsteps and showing her determination... it's just really well made. My only complain is the game's length, being really short. i was expecting it to be atleist a little longer than Tomb Raider 2013, but both games took me exactly 10 hours each to beat on ''Tomb Raider'' difficulty ( normal i guess ), which is a little sad to be honest... But hey, it's not the end of the world, replayability is there, though i don't think it's really something that i'll do. Great game, definitly buy it if you've played the 2013, or even if it's your first TR game.

reviewText:
Why is it, that in most games with a skill system the protagonists forgets everything I taught her in the previous game?

This game really got me. Far more than it predecessor, although I think it is a little bit behind on the story it still does everything right. You have to explore the world in order to become a real tomb raider or you just rush through the main story, which still manages to get the right atmosphere.

I have to admit the parts were Lara swims through icy water and then reacts to it really makes for great feelings.

The characters lack a little bit of depts, the well known flashbacks of the last part were something I missed.

The game plays well as it was expected, while this time the hunting is far more importent and the crafting is an interesting part of combat, since explosives are not carriable any more.

Will play again for sure.

reviewText:
It's another Tomb Raider. Quite similar to the 2013 release gameplay-wise. If you loved it then, you'll love it again.

Pros:
+ a couple of original tombs to discover
+ great start
+ fun bow/arrow gameplay
+ a few very cool puzzles
+ some great locations
+ exploring
+ a bit Uncharted feeling
+ a few boss fights, that require a tad bit of strategy
+ DLC: Baba Yaga, Temple of the Witch is a cool and a bit different DLC. Has some exploring, puzzling, collecting and IMO the most interesting boss fight. Adds maybe an hour tops.

Cons:
- dull, predictable story
- some forced Call of Duty style passages
- mediocre skills, quite some useless in it (dodge kill)
- the landscape is not very diverse. Usually it's snowy and dark, sadly they didn't make much of the level in Syria
- general gunfights are tedious and not much fun. Enemies are boring

If you're new to the restarted franchise, I'd recommend picking up the 2013 version and play that first. It introduces Lara Croft and the whole franchise and has a bit more diverse level set. And it's much cheaper.

Story is really not much to speak of, especially if you played Indiana Jones, Uncharted and the likes.

Still, it's a solid game.

reviewText:
My god, this game is so good.
I thought nothing could surpass 2013's quality, that the sequal would end up being bad. I was dead wrong, and Square Enix surprised me yet again.

I'm going to try to divide this review into several parts, to explain each aspect carefully.

-----------------Combat--------------------

The combat is just as great as it always was, if not better and smoother. The pick, bow, and firearms feel like they have some real impact behind them, and each hit feels brutal. Lara controls like a dream, and the fact you can go for stealth for almost every encounter if you so choose, or go in guns blazing (if you have a death wish) is great and I really appreciate that fact.you can use the environment to your advantage and attack enemies with exploding gas, lanterns, bottles, and probably much more (Have not finished game yet). Said bottles can also be used as a distraction to lure enemies away from groups.


--------------Map--------------------


The areas to explore are enormous, if not triple the size of 2013, and every location is beautiful to behold. there are tons of places to explore that are off the beaten path, tons of materials and relics to collect, numerous wildlife to farm for furs, caves and ziplines galore, and plenty of writings to translate. Exploring is very rewarding, as you will always find a little something in every corner. Don't be afraid to comb every area over! It is worth it!


-----------------Tombs------------------


Tombs are huge and well-hidden. No longer are they just one big room" like they were in 2013
date: but they are huge areas with connecting areas you need to use together to solve the connected puzzle. There's also plenty of salvage and relics here
recommended: and the reward for completing  a tomb is more than just some little item
hoursPlayed:
you receive skills and ancient weapon parts. Very much worth doing.


-----------Visuals-----------------------

This game is absolutely beautiful. One of the best looking games I have seen in a while. Not a surprise
voteText:
Square is pretty well known to make some good-looking games.

---------Enemy AI--------------

These enemies are smart. They will flank yyou
helpfulPercent: flush you out with grenades
votesHelpful: bumrush you if they vastly outnumber you
votesTotal: they can be a pain

you have to shoot them while they run all over the place. In packs.

-----------Side quests----------

Yes

You can do side quests you receive from friendly NPCs/Items that net you cool rewards like weapon upgrades and tools like the lockpick. 100% worth completing these.\n\nAll in all I would say that this is the best game I have played this year so far. Even though it's only been about a month in 2016 at the time of this review

reviewText:
Did you like the first reboot? Well, this is more of the same - or rather more of the good things of the reboot. Less QTE's, more tombs and caves and exploration. Still some silly problems with bining keys to mouse on PC. It shows to press the [] button for various actions, but if you have two thumbbuttons used - you won't know which ones until you tried - and most likely died a few times.

The story is slightly tighter this time around, more focused - and that is both good and bad. If you're a completionist than it will feel like you leave people to die to be able to go off the beaten path to explore and find treasure. You also have to leave certain tombs and treasures behind since you will lack certain gear and features that you lock up later on in the story line.

The expeditions are fun DLC and really should come in more flavours since this is what most will be doing after they beat the game - or well only be doing since this is the real challenge.

The game has some technical flaws and hickups. There is a hguge FPS drop in expeditions that occurs with a few minutes regualr intervention that makes it feel like something is going on that shouldn't be happening. The single player part runs with most things on on my spec flawlessly. I don't use occular and lens flaires and depth of field - but other than that - I have most things on except the hair. And I have a steady 80-110 FPS regardless of fights in firelit places.
Gameplay issues range from minor nitpicks as to how the camera works and you have little control meaning that forward moves your character sideways end vice versa in some parts of the game. Sometimes you can't see where you are going, meaning that you have to die to your death hoping you are on the right track and then redo some climbing/jumping routines - I had rather seen more difficult pathfinding as an obstacle than the camera itself as your biggest problem.

Hopefully coming patches will make the expeditions better optimized since that is really something nice - oh and that's were most of your pre-order and DLC extras will come into play.

The card system is to beef out and tweak your expeditions adventures.

EDIT notes: after finishing the game and Baba Yaga DLC.
So, the game is ended and for that I have to give cred. I don't finish all my games but this one I did. The game gets slightly tedious at the end, trying to sweep the areas looking for missing documents, loot and item chests. But all in all - a nice game. Baba Yaga wasn't a hit though - if you think you're missing out due to this one - rest easy - it is not worth the time. I got a bit disapointed here with the season pass so far. Hopefully something that adds to replayability will come out because I have no intention of playing this again on other difficulties etc. In the end, you do get more of the tedious fights from the first game. This time around it is easier to either sneak past - or have some cat and mouse game out of the fights - but still, a few too many to my liking.

reviewText:
This game is awesome, but it isn't perfect. Ill be making a list of pros and cons and then finally give it a rating.

Pros:
-Awesome parkour
-Dense map
-Finding weapon parts is fun usually
-There are good graphics enhancers for those who dont like the washed out look (I used one and personally it made the game feel much more alive)
-The crafting and looting system is relatively good
-The plot is somewhat interesting but not enough to make me feel emotionally attached
-It isn't trying to replicate another games mechanics (in terms of parkour)
-animations look bloody awesome
-weather affects characters attire (snow can get caught in her hair and fall on her clothes)
-Mouse and keyboard are well mapped

Cons:
-Game seems short lived even after taking time to listen to audio tapes and watch cutscenes etc
-Map is small
-Side missions didnt give me any motivation after finishing the main story
-The story missions arent long enough for you to unlock everything while focusing on it.
-many outfits so little time
-Poor optimization (but bearable unlike ac unity)
-Without reshading this game lacks effects and a nice color palet. its also somewhat more blurry
-This doesnt apply to everyone but in the sequel I'd like the game to be more open and long with a more gripping plot and add more character development (crafting new tools, more unique weapons, side quests that dont apply to the main story or anyone related to the group/village.) But by far what I needed the most is a bigger map with areas of different climates (Id love to go back to Syria and explore more do more missions etc)4

Overall I rate this game 8.5/10
Id buy this game when its on sale unless you really want to play it

reviewText:
If you liked the last Tomb Raider, you will most likely enjoy this.

+ Lara's character is a bit more developed here than the last game
+ Tombs are fun to explore, and satisfying to complete
+ Excellent visuals, with many options to tweak.. prepare to take many screenshots
+ Lots of environmental interaction (snow, wetness, dirt) and little details to add to immersion
+ Best hair physics ever

- Too much gunplay, not enough crazy complicated tombs.
- Certain areas of the game are significantly larger than others, causing framerate drops
- Survival senses and Lara's words can easily point you to tomb solutions, taking out some of the fun in solving it yourself

Overal this is an excellent adventure game, and I had a lot of fun with it. 9/10

reviewText: Normally I'm not a fan of linear games, but this one I like. And it's weird because I'll be climbing along a cliff side, and the rock I'm clinging to will crumble away and fall along with me, and In the midst of my fall I will wonder not whether or not I'm going to survive the fall, but how in the world am I going to get back because there only seems to be one path available to any given place in this game. And the reason I tolerate this, I think, is because the sacrifice of logic is made to be worth it with exhilerating moments of engagement in the story. I feel what Lara is feeling when something goes wrong with my only plan, and I'm left with no apparent options, I feel trapped even though I'm not, but Lara is, and suddenly I find a solution, and it feels like a miracle. Experiencing the miracles are what redeems the logical falacies, and trapping nature of linear games. Just based on this I would recommend this game, but there are some things that may make some of you hesitate in buying it, and I'd like to warn you of those.\nThe most noteworthy is the grinding required to aquire certain things. This warning is only for those of you who happen to not want to perform genocide on wildlife that is nearly equatable in magnitude to the holocaust in order to attain the best bow, rifle, pistol, or shotgun upgrades for any or all of the variants of these weapons. I say this because the crafting requirements for weapon upgrades often requires many resources from animals. To be fair you can go through the game without destroying local ecosystems because the weapon upgrades are not entirely necessary, but if you are a perfectionest with a conscience you may be putting yourself into a terrible predicament by playing this game.\nThe other reason you may not want to buy this game is because you won't get much time out of it. Like I said it's a linear game so there's not much replayability to be had, and all the game has to offer to keep you engaged after you have finished the story is a thing called expeditions, which basically allows you to repeat specific parts of the story with arcade-like challenges. I find these boring, and I don't think they are good enough to maintain my interest in the game. I finished the story in about 19 hours, but you may finish the game in less if you don't get caught up in slaughtering the wildlife, so if you think <19 hours of a great story is worth 60 dollars minus 1 cent then I recommend you get this game, if not wait for a sale, or just don't buy it.

reviewText:
Making a good sequel to a game that defied all expectations and became an instant classic like 2013's Tomb Raider is quite the challenge. And I can safely say that the people at Crystal Dynamics have succeeded in this endeavor. Rise of the Tomb Raider is just as good as its predecesor, if not better.
In this new adventure we follow Lara as she tries to clean her father's name. The story is filled with fantasy and adventure, and is supported by the usual document collectibles that you find throughout the game. Learning how people felt and how they survived is a thrilling journey that will make you want to find all of them so you can learn the whole story.
From the gameplay point of view, there are no complaints what so ever. It is as good as the previous game and there are some new mechanics that make it compelling to go back to previous areas just to kill some enemies in various creative ways. And also there's the threat of nature, as wild animals will fight you as you trespass into their natural habitat. Everything feels smooth and not forced upon you, and this is rare to find in a AAA game these days.
Now, from the graphical point of view, let me say that if you assume you can run this game with a rig that could manage the previous one, then you are mistaken. The environments look gorgeous and every detail is breath taking. But if your PC is not prepared for a highly demanding game, then you won't be able to enjoy said environments because you will barely be able to run the game. Specially if your graphics card is AMD. The folks at NVIDIA made sure that any AMD user that plays this game does not get to enjoy it at its full capacity. The optimization is terrible, and even the newest AMD cards can't handle some of these options without dropping frames like hot potatoes. Be aware before you buy this game: you need a powerful processor, lots of RAM and an NVIDIA graphics card to play it without DPS issues. You can still play it with an AMD card just fine if you don't care about the sudden frame drops in big places and the occasional crash. That's about the only negative thing I have to say about this game. And it seems to be happening with every game powered by NVIDIA these days. It's annoying as hell.
TL;DR: This game is amazing in every aspect except its graphical optimization. If you can run it, buy it. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
Now, before I start with this review, this is just for ze lulz, because this game is worth every penny of its purchase price.

Rise of The Tomb Raider is visually one of the best games there are, hands down. Playing on an i5-4690k and GTX 750Ti, and it still looks very, very good. Yes, there are a few drops here and there, but nothing major that could ruin the gameplay.

The story, ooh sweet story. Rise of the Tomb Raider is better in every aspect than its reboot in 2013. More interesting story, more tombs, larger map, more collectibles etc.

I have been a fan of Tomb Raider games since I was a child, and at some point, the Tomb Raider games just didn't feel good anymore, they were boring, but time passed, and they made Tomb Raider (2013), which was a masterpiece, a game that everyone just have to have in their library at some point, honestly I didn't think they would make a better Tomb Raider game than the one released in 2013, oh how wrong I was.

Rise of The Tomb Raider is a technical masterpiece that will consume you, if you're a fan of adventure games with some puzzles and action. It's like that one student at the back of the class getting all the answers right while others just scream and fool around. If you call yourself a gamer, you NEED to buy this right now! Hands down one of the best games in 2016 that came to PC.

Oh, and Lara's ♥♥♥ looks nice in this, too.

reviewText:
So, I wanted to beat this before I wrote a review.  When I finished, I had completed roughly 70% of the content.  I missed a few of the tombs, but saw enough to know what they were like, and some of the weapon components.

All in all, this was a solid game, but not something I would recommend buying at full price for two reasons: 1) There isn't all that much gameplay to be had and 2) Though it's well done, there's nothing life-changing here.  The most I'd pay, if I could do it again, is 40 dollars.

This is a nonexhaustive review, I listed the things that I've most commonly seen commented on and anything that jumped out at me.

TLDR: Good graphics, but mundane setting.  Decent story, but a bit short.  Average overall mechanics (crafting, combat).  Enjoyed my time played, but less than the former title.  Though i recommend it, I would not pay more than 40 dollars.

Pros:

- Graphics.  The graphics are extremely well done.  There is a lot of polish, nothing too clunky (the occasional visual glitch)

- Tombs.  Tombs were pretty solid; simple enough that they wouldn't totally frustrate you, but not so mindlessly easy that they had no value.

- Story.  This would probably be more appropriately listed in the neutral" category.  I didn't find the story particularly thrilling.  It was extremely straightforward
date: there were not any exciting twists.  However
recommended: it was good enough to keep me playing and did not detract from my experience at all.  Given that I wanted to see how it ended
hoursPlayed: even though the end was predictable

reviewText: the ''sequel'' to Tomb Raider 2013 ( because this is Lara's first tomb raid, so not exactly a sequel but... ) is as good or even better than Tomb Raider 2013. The gameplay is relatively the same, which is not a bad thing since it already was really great, and in ROTTR they've added new movements and abilities to this already great gameplay. Graphics wise.... it's jaw-dropping, this game looks so good ( maxed out atleist ), it's the best graphics i've ever seen in a video game and it runs great ( apart from the texture quality settings, if you have anything less than 4 Gb of VRam, don't bother going ''very high'' you'll stutter ) and there's a lot of options here as well. Story now, it's great. I mean, it's Lara's first Tomb, following her dad's footsteps and showing her determination... it's just really well made. My only complain is the game's length, being really short. i was expecting it to be atleist a little longer than Tomb Raider 2013, but both games took me exactly 10 hours each to beat on ''Tomb Raider'' difficulty ( normal i guess ), which is a little sad to be honest... But hey, it's not the end of the world, replayability is there, though i don't think it's really something that i'll do. Great game, definitly buy it if you've played the 2013, or even if it's your first TR game.

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider is another step in the right direction for Lara Croft since the series nadir - The Angel of Darkness. This game takes the formula set by the previous game and adds a few flourishes but ultimately plays out the same.
Graphically one of the best looking games ive seen its a visual treat to see Lara running and exploring her way across forgotten corners of Syria, and later Russia.
The level design is great with huge open areas with multiple routes to reach a goal, and often side quests can be obtained to further reward additional backtracking/exploration.
Story wise, its a solid entry - Lara is searching for an artifact that is rumoured to grant immortality with a shadowy cult also trying to get the artifact for more nefarious reasons .
The gameplay is solid, and the levelling up process straight forward. Crafting gets more of a heads up this time round and parts need to be collected and created in order to make new weapons and ammo to further assist Lara on her journey.
If you enjoyed the last Lara Croft outing this will also appeal but ne thing the game developers need to get their heads around is the fact that Lara Croft is known for raiding Tombs and very little of that happens in this game and indeed the last game. You could swap Lara out for Nathan Drake and call this Uncharted and noone would question it as they are both now very similar games. Get Lara back to raiding Tombs!!!!

reviewText: One of the most fun games I've ever played.  The abilities are fun to level up.  Hunting is a blast.  Crafting is rewarding.  Stealth is as fun as jumping off an ancient artifact to stab somebody in the face.  Rise of the Tomb Raider is also one of the top three prettiest games I've ever played.  Go drool over my screenshots.    The puzzles are too easy, but I spammed the survival mode button.  The combat and action scenes in this game (playable and cinematic) will get your heart pumping.  The game doesn't have a whole lot of replay value unless you are a completionist.  I really enjoyed the story in this game.  I never tried the cards but I'm going to because there's big head mode, sometimes-enemies-will-explode-when-looted mode, infinite ammo mode, and all sorts of other fun-looking cards that make the game easier, more challenging, and/or fun.  I do plan to go back and 100% the game.  Then the completionist in me be will be like YEAH!" #Borderlands2 #Gaige #sickreviewnia :B1:"

reviewText:
What can I say? I got this game for free with my graphics card, and hoping that they would have improved on TR2013 I decided to play it to see if they made any improvements to the reboot (instead of giving the code to someone that acutally wanted to play the game), but there was nothing new to be found. It felt like it could very well have been an expansion pack to the original TR2013. The shooting is still bad. The guns still sound like BB guns, and the controls are as bad and unresponsive as they were in TR2013. I can not comment too much on the story since I only played three hours of it, but what I got was boring and not very original. The one improvement I found was that they had cut down on the QTE's, but they still used them to much for my taste.

Graphics wise the game is great. Nothing more to say really. The game went for a photo-realistic look instead of having an unique artsyle, which means the game will look old in an year or two. I always prefer when a game chooses to have a nice artstyle instead of going for photo-realistic graphics, since games that have a nice artstyle age way better. Just look at Wind waker. That game still looks great to this day.

And tombs. Tombs where boring. I got trough two of them before I decided to uninstall the game, and they were both way too easy. The game holds your hand way too much. If you are presented with even the simplest of puzzles, the game will have Lara comment on what she needs to do to solve it, which completely ruins the whole point of having a puzzle. This segment will represent the process of getting trough a tomb in this game:

''Hmm, I wonder what I need to do to get past this part?'' I wondered as I was presented with a puzzle.

''Why not do that and then that to solve it?'' Lara then said and the puzzle had solved itself for me.

I hate when games treat their players as if they are two years old, and this game does it exceptionally well.

This is very subjective, but I don't Laras' voice actor. I don't know what it is, but I find it unbearable to listen to her for more than 5 seconds at a time.

If you liked the original TR2013, you will like this. But if you did not, you should pass on this glorified expansion.

reviewText:
A game with almost as much of a collect a thon as your avid Ubisoft game. It feels like half the game time, if you were to do everything, is just boring side stuff. The Tombs are still only optional and not part of the story, geez. It's called Tomb Raider. The graphics looks good, but the game is horribly optimized. The cutscenes are stepping way too deep into the uncanny valley and the dialogs are horrible. The voice acting and directing for Lara is so cringy and just out right bad. Her characters is anything but likeable aswell. The gun/bow play is improved and you now have a crafting system, TLOU-style but much faster. It speeds up the killing and it all feels a bit to easy. As before everything is made of graham crackers and kids glue and gets destroyed just from having Lara lookt at it.

I only recommend this game if you have a beast of a computer (980Ti or better) or can settle with capping at 30fps. Still, look up vids about how well your system would do. Because damn, this game is dropping framerate all over the place in big areas. About the price. I feel like spending 45 bucks, which I did, was way too much for this experience. I'd say wait til winter 2016 and buy it sub 20 bucks.

Cheers!

reviewText:
I give 8 out of 10 for Rise of the Tomb Raider so far. (75% completion for finishing the main story)

For a game that released in 2016. (xbox one on late 2015) Graphic looks decent and runing around 25-30 FPS on med high setting on my 5 years old desktop. Gameplay itself has several improvment over the the predecessor. I didnt find an major bug during the gameplay.

Challenge mode is one of the biggest improvment and complete optional during the main story and it involved some basic puzzle solving  which takes a little bit of time to figure out. (otherwise the game feel like thrid person shooter) Side quest is a bit boring due to its game mode (either kill or get something) but it gives u some reward other than coins or resources.

Landscapes stick with snowmountains, deep undergournd ruins and villages in Siberia for 90% of the game. Desert and oasis in Syria appear in the second chapter which only takes no more than 30 mins gameplay. Sad thing is the predecessor already has too much snow and i personal seek different environment. But the good part is the game has large amount of scret tomb location (include challenge mode) compare to the predecessor, and it actually gives u bonus such as weapon parts or skills instead of just exploring.

I assume the game will take between 15 to 25 hours depend on ur play style. I played under survival difficulty and complete all challenge mode on the way through. Might take 30 hours or more to collect all the relic and other stuff.

Overall the game is decent, and much like the first Tomb Raider reboot, with few enhancement. Especially the Challenge mode makes the game more like a Tomb Raider" after all."

reviewText:
RISE OF THE TOMB RAIDER EXECUTES THE FRANCHISE FORMULA WITH CONFIDENCE.

In many ways, Rise of the Tomb Raider could be viewed as a fairly modest sequel. It successfully builds off Crystal Dynamics' excellent reboot, but it doesn't introduce any massive changes; the scope is greater but still in spitting distance of the previous game. But successfully regaining the feeling created in an extremely good game is no small feat. This is the inauguration of Tomb Raider as a formula once more, but for now, it's a formula I'm happy revisiting.

9.5/10

reviewText:
rating: worth buying at sale price (<30€)
score: 7.5/10 - good
similar games: Uncharted, Prince of Persia
tags: exploration, puzzles, third person shooter

Almost everything has been improved compared to the Tomb Raider Reboot from 2013 ... except the story. The story of Tomb Raider 2013 was already REALLY bad and had nothing but forgettable characters. Rise of the Tomb Raider also has nothing but forgettable characters, the story is also really bad, but what ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off the most is how extremely serious this game is. There is NO humour AT ALL, even though the topics and the story of this game are extremely silly things.
Because of this the Uncharted series will always be better.
After the boring prologue I had a lot of fun with RotTR and I thought this might be a strong contender for GOTY, but the more I continued the more I got dissapointed and the terrible story just left me with a dissapointed feeling at the end. Still, the game has a lot of good things about it, which could easily make it a 9/10 just by have LESS story, because it is SO bad.
What I liked the most about this game is how much bigger the areas are, how much more encouraged you are to explore and how much more puzzles you can do. This also makes this game feel much more like the first generation of Tomb Raider games. Combat is also improved, but not by much. Unlike TR2013 though, you don't get thrown into a combat situation and then get attacked by waves of enemies. Here in most situations the enemies won't know that you are there, so you can always plan your attack first and go stealthy. Problem is that the game is so ♥♥♥♥ing easy even on the highest difficulty, actually it's simply broken. You get waay to much ammo and resources for everything which allows you to craft as much poison/fire/explosive arrows as you want, which are by far the most overpowered weapons in the game. With 1 poison arrow you can take down a group of the most armored enemies in the game. Not only that, but you will have millions of healing material, so you can always heal yourself in combat. Especially because of the level design there is always cover which you can use and quickly heal yourself. It gets even more ridiculous when you upgrade your healing ability, which they added because apparently it wasn't easy enough already. With the healing upgrade you can heal yourself almost instantly. I actually didn't die a single time in combat in this game on the highest difficulty. The combat was still fun, and the good thing is there wasn't THAT much combat as in TR2013.
What dissapointed me about the second half of the game is that there weren't these big hub areas anymore, where you can freely explore, do side missions and stuff like that. The second half was completely rushed and you were always attacked by enemies. I completed the game in 12 hours and I did almost all side missions and all tombs except one. 12 hours is really short.
Visually the game was really impressive, it had some really nice places, good variety and panoramas. But I had some frame drops in some places on my GTX 970 which was annoying (without AA, textures no high).

I think if the story and ending wasn't so bad, I wouldn't be left with such a dissapointed feeling and like the game much more. I don't recommend buying at full price, because the game is too short.

reviewText:
My god, this game is so good.
I thought nothing could surpass 2013's quality, that the sequal would end up being bad. I was dead wrong, and Square Enix surprised me yet again.

I'm going to try to divide this review into several parts, to explain each aspect carefully.

-----------------Combat--------------------

The combat is just as great as it always was, if not better and smoother. The pick, bow, and firearms feel like they have some real impact behind them, and each hit feels brutal. Lara controls like a dream, and the fact you can go for stealth for almost every encounter if you so choose, or go in guns blazing (if you have a death wish) is great and I really appreciate that fact.you can use the environment to your advantage and attack enemies with exploding gas, lanterns, bottles, and probably much more (Have not finished game yet). Said bottles can also be used as a distraction to lure enemies away from groups.


--------------Map--------------------


The areas to explore are enormous, if not triple the size of 2013, and every location is beautiful to behold. there are tons of places to explore that are off the beaten path, tons of materials and relics to collect, numerous wildlife to farm for furs, caves and ziplines galore, and plenty of writings to translate. Exploring is very rewarding, as you will always find a little something in every corner. Don't be afraid to comb every area over! It is worth it!


-----------------Tombs------------------


Tombs are huge and well-hidden. No longer are they just one big room" like they were in 2013
date: but they are huge areas with connecting areas you need to use together to solve the connected puzzle. There's also plenty of salvage and relics here
recommended: and the reward for completing  a tomb is more than just some little item
hoursPlayed:
you receive skills and ancient weapon parts. Very much worth doing.


-----------Visuals-----------------------

This game is absolutely beautiful. One of the best looking games I have seen in a while. Not a surprise
voteText:
Square is pretty well known to make some good-looking games.

---------Enemy AI--------------

These enemies are smart. They will flank yyou

reviewText: Normally I'm not a fan of linear games, but this one I like. And it's weird because I'll be climbing along a cliff side, and the rock I'm clinging to will crumble away and fall along with me, and In the midst of my fall I will wonder not whether or not I'm going to survive the fall, but how in the world am I going to get back because there only seems to be one path available to any given place in this game. And the reason I tolerate this, I think, is because the sacrifice of logic is made to be worth it with exhilerating moments of engagement in the story. I feel what Lara is feeling when something goes wrong with my only plan, and I'm left with no apparent options, I feel trapped even though I'm not, but Lara is, and suddenly I find a solution, and it feels like a miracle. Experiencing the miracles are what redeems the logical falacies, and trapping nature of linear games. Just based on this I would recommend this game, but there are some things that may make some of you hesitate in buying it, and I'd like to warn you of those.\nThe most noteworthy is the grinding required to aquire certain things. This warning is only for those of you who happen to not want to perform genocide on wildlife that is nearly equatable in magnitude to the holocaust in order to attain the best bow, rifle, pistol, or shotgun upgrades for any or all of the variants of these weapons. I say this because the crafting requirements for weapon upgrades often requires many resources from animals. To be fair you can go through the game without destroying local ecosystems because the weapon upgrades are not entirely necessary, but if you are a perfectionest with a conscience you may be putting yourself into a terrible predicament by playing this game.\nThe other reason you may not want to buy this game is because you won't get much time out of it. Like I said it's a linear game so there's not much replayability to be had, and all the game has to offer to keep you engaged after you have finished the story is a thing called expeditions, which basically allows you to repeat specific parts of the story with arcade-like challenges. I find these boring, and I don't think they are good enough to maintain my interest in the game. I finished the story in about 19 hours, but you may finish the game in less if you don't get caught up in slaughtering the wildlife, so if you think <19 hours of a great story is worth 60 dollars minus 1 cent then I recommend you get this game, if not wait for a sale, or just don't buy it.

reviewText:
If you loved the first game this is a further step forward in every way. On the higher difficulties it's actually a challenge now, the firefights are very strategic and satisfying and plenty of tombs to uncover. Be warned though it's like Crysis, you need an incredibly powerful rig to run it once you get to the lost city stages. My frame rate on an r290 fluctuates wildly from 60fps down to the teens on the high setting and tessellation set to 8x in crimson control panel, playing only 1080p. This is with the latest beta driver. I thoroughly disagree with the reviewers who say there's not much difference between the quality settings, there is a gulf. If you have the rig to run this congrats, I thought meeting the recommended specs was enough but it's sadly not at least on AMD. A g-sync or free-sync monitor is recommended to address the frame rate fluctuations. I am hoping they can add further optimisations to the frame rate because it really struggles in parts. Can consume up to 7gb of video ram on highest texture settings, even on high it's saturated my r290 4GB buffer. But boy it can look beautiful.

Update: I have updated this section now that I have tested the latest AMD Driver 15.3.1 and the new Patch which both support DirectX 12. This game is incredibly single core heavy in DirectX 11 mode, even an overclocked FX processor (my 8320 is running @ 4.7Ghz) is not fast enough to smoothly run this game. However with the DirectX12 support now added, the game spreads the load evenly across all the cores eliminating the large frame rate fluctuations. Coupled with AMD's optimisations and the game can easily hold 50fps just about all the time and closes in on the golden 60fps on the default High game setting at 1080p. There are still a few demanding areas but these drop to the 40s instead of the teens now so they aren't are noticable unless you are looking for them.

The future of AMD and DirectX 12 looks quite rosy ;)

reviewText:
If you liked the last Tomb Raider, you will most likely enjoy this.

+ Lara's character is a bit more developed here than the last game
+ Tombs are fun to explore, and satisfying to complete
+ Excellent visuals, with many options to tweak.. prepare to take many screenshots
+ Lots of environmental interaction (snow, wetness, dirt) and little details to add to immersion
+ Best hair physics ever

- Too much gunplay, not enough crazy complicated tombs.
- Certain areas of the game are significantly larger than others, causing framerate drops
- Survival senses and Lara's words can easily point you to tomb solutions, taking out some of the fun in solving it yourself

Overal this is an excellent adventure game, and I had a lot of fun with it. 9/10

reviewText: Yep... Square Enix does it again with astonishing graphics. Lara is smoking hot and beautifully modelled. If you loved the last game Tomb Raider" and the way the reboot went then you will love this game too.\n\nShame it's gamesworks this time around which
recommended: screws people's performance on the highest settings. This game needs optimisation still for when it is loading from the drive but most people's performance will be tanking because of Nvidia's usual BS.\n\nSo turn tessellation right down in your driver settings and turn off the HBAO+ to restore most of the performance dips. You will still get some stuttering when it is loading in this version 1.0 early build. This is because I only have 8GB of RAM and it is using the windows pagefile. Make sure you have your pagefile on an SSD
hoursPlayed: if you have one
voteText:
when you are running less than 16GB of RAM. Otherwise do as I suggest and your performance will be mostly fine with everything else on max.

I am running an FX-8120 and a 7950 and I am getting a pretty solid 40-50 fps from the steam counter.

EDIT: Ok so I got to the 3rd part called "Soviet Installation" and my frame rate tanked. I had to drop from "very high" to "high" texture detail. I'm guessing I ran out of VRAM cause that's all it took to bump my frame rate right back up again and I couldn't notice any difference at all at 1080p. I suspect "v high" textures are just badly compressed. This game sure is punishing on hardware... but it sure is beatuiful."

reviewText:
Now, before I start with this review, this is just for ze lulz, because this game is worth every penny of its purchase price.

Rise of The Tomb Raider is visually one of the best games there are, hands down. Playing on an i5-4690k and GTX 750Ti, and it still looks very, very good. Yes, there are a few drops here and there, but nothing major that could ruin the gameplay.

The story, ooh sweet story. Rise of the Tomb Raider is better in every aspect than its reboot in 2013. More interesting story, more tombs, larger map, more collectibles etc.

I have been a fan of Tomb Raider games since I was a child, and at some point, the Tomb Raider games just didn't feel good anymore, they were boring, but time passed, and they made Tomb Raider (2013), which was a masterpiece, a game that everyone just have to have in their library at some point, honestly I didn't think they would make a better Tomb Raider game than the one released in 2013, oh how wrong I was.

Rise of The Tomb Raider is a technical masterpiece that will consume you, if you're a fan of adventure games with some puzzles and action. It's like that one student at the back of the class getting all the answers right while others just scream and fool around. If you call yourself a gamer, you NEED to buy this right now! Hands down one of the best games in 2016 that came to PC.

Oh, and Lara's ♥♥♥ looks nice in this, too.

reviewText:
In short, 7.5/10

Pros:
+ Gorgeous scenery
+ High quality cutscenes with good voice acting
+ More diverse environment than prequel
+ Larger and harder puzzles than prequel
+ Exciting action setpieces without being too much
+ Generally good character writing
+ Not-so-cheap collectibles

Okays:
= Acceptable story
= Marginally improved enemy AI

Cons
- Still not enough exploration - only 2 major hub regions.
- Too easy puzzles - each puzzle piece rarely took me more than 5 minutes.
- Handholding - white paint and voice comment - not to mention survival instinct - telling you where to go
- Overpowered Lara even on high difficulties
- Cheap ending with disappointing resolution - Predictable and did not satisfy my curiosity

I recommend non-casual gamers to impose a self-challenge of not using map and not using survival sense during the game."

reviewText:
After 11 hours of gameplay, I finished the main story.

The first minutes inside the game are fantastic. You have a breathtaking graphic, insanely fluid movements, wonderful voiced characters and of course the cutest and sexiest girl in the gaming world: Lara Croft.

The game is linear, even tho you are kinda allowed to roam around and do stuff, you basically wanna follow the red string of the story. You will occasionally encounter some special hidden quests which are fun to do and give you a good reward. You solve everything in typical Lara Croft style, climbing walls and jumping off roofs. And all of that doesnt only ♥♥♥♥ing feel awesome, it also looks awesome.

Your character can level up, and you can invest points per Level into abilities, which are divided into 3 main groups. It allows you to customize the way you wanna finish the game. Do you prefer shooting around, stealthing around or building traps? It's all up to you.
Your Weapons can also be upgraded, in the same way as your character.

I really enjoyed it. Maybe because I have a huge thing for British girls. Or, and thats what I think, because this game just combines some of the core elements of some good games and brings us a wonderful next gen Lara Croft!

reviewText:
If you spoke to me when I was a kid and told me that one day there would be Tomb Raider games where Lara Croft didn't use her iconic dual Desert Eagles but she instead swapped them for a Bow, I would shun you and probably throw a tantrum.
But here I am in 2016, having just finished the second game and I am beyond amazed. This game takes the best aspects from the last game and adds things we all missed from the original games... RAIDING TOMBS!

PROS
-Great Graphics
-Amazing gameplay. Especially the crafting system when in combat
-Pretty solid story that keeps you intrigued
-You can finish the entire game with the Bow. The weapons found later on in the story were not automatically superior

CONS
-Constant hunting in areas for things like coins or strongboxes tends to get boring
-Combat was never really challanging. Bears were more of a challange than 10 or more Trinity Soldiers
-Framerate drops in movies (under 20fps for me in some places)

As a Tomb Raider fan since I was just out of nappies, who started his first Tomb Raider experience by being allowed to sit on my brothers lap and press the space bar to draw Lara's weapons when she needed to them, I Definitely think this game is a game worthy of the Tomb Raider name and any one who is a fan of the originals or just the newer ones should give it a playthrough.

OVERALL SCORE 9/10

reviewText:
This game does not give off a good first impression. The beginning is heavily scripted. Walk forwards, watch something bad happen, press X to not die, etc. Follow the linear path, watch the cutscenes. Please, give me gameplay already. Fortunately, after a short attempt to impress players with gee whiz cutscene action, it does start delivering the goods.

The gameplay mixes platforming, traversal (climbing and the like), combat of both the direct and stealth variety, puzzle solving, and exploration and discovery. There's a lot of good to be found in these elements.

Lara's jumping is fluid and fun to control. You can actually aim her jumps a little bit in mid-air, and her climbing is also quite fluid. She can double jump" up walls
hoursPlayed: and can climb icy and rocky walls with her pickaxe. You have a ton of control over these elements
voteText: as opposed to the stiff movement of the later Uncharted games
helpfulPercent: and combining these moves together is a lot of fun.\n\nCombat tends to allow for many options. For example

reviewText: THe first 20 hours I found myself thinking this game was a buggy,  lesser version of the 2013 TR release. However, once you get over how weird Lara's face looks, the horrendous mouth animations during dialogue both in and out of cinematic, that's when the game actually has a new sort of charm.\nIt might take a few tries to get your grpahics to where your sweet-spot is, but a lot of the issues reported have not happened to me and I always fine tune my settings instead of assuming one-size fits all. I'd describe it as VERY HIGH settings with the exception of one or two parameters.\nThis game comes into its own where the alst one failed miserably: multiplayer. You don't play against others on the same map, no. But you do have an arcade style leaderboard and expeditions menu which offers huge amounts of customizations via cards. It's incredibly addicting and I've spent too much time trying to get the high scores and I will spend more.

reviewText: Rise of the Tomb Raider's level design and pacing make it a masterpiece among action-adventure games. The levels are built to be replayable but doesn't make it obvious the first time through. This makes it feel like everything you do will constantly drive the game forward but never closes you off from collectibles or going back to take screenshots after the action is through, which the jaw-dropping art will make you want to do. The pacing conveys the sense of urgency mirrored in the story but speeds up and slows down effectively. Characters are developed in audio logs as well as in cinematics and interactions with Lara. This teired approach allows you to get a feeling about the characters without being overbearing. This game also brings Tomb Raider closer to it's roots after the 2013's origin story, Lara is back to treasure hunting fiend she used to be. The length of the game hit the sweet spot of ~30 hours for 100% completion run, including the Baba Yaga dlc, and can be extended through the Replay and Endurance gamemodes. Thank you to developers for such an amazing and bug-free experience. (well worth noting in this era of releasing unfinished games) I think this game is a big win for everyone involved and probably the best Tomb Raider game ever. Well worth the launch price.

reviewText:
Excellent Game!

Up until 2013, the Tomb Raider franchise as a whole had been steadily declining since it's glory days on the PS1.  I loved those early games, but the sequels got stale over the years.

The 2013 Reboot was a breath of fresh air, and one of the best reboots of all time, alongside J.J. Abrahms 2009 Star Trek.  I immensely enjoyed Tomb Raider, and after owning it on PS3 (multiple playthroughs) I purchased it on a Steam sale and completed another playthrough.

This game is even better in my opinion than the 2013 Tomb Raider.  In the first game, Lara was constantly on the brink of death, always running and seemingly fighting a neverending uphill battle.  This time, it really feels like she is where she wants to be, and much more in control than in the first game.

The controls are wonderful, I use a xbox controller and it feels very nice.  The Tomb puzzles are not too tough and are completed fairly quickly, which is very good as it doesn't bog down the gameplay and keeps up the pace.  The combat is nice, and there are more weapons and options in this game than it's direct predecessor.

The combat is well paced, with very well directed set pieces throughout.  The game doesn't slow down too much, even when I take a break to hunt more deer or rabbits for the next crafting upgrade.

The Graphics.  Oh God the graphics.  This game is absolutely beautiful.  I wish I could post a screenshot in this review.  My specs aren't bleeding edge or top-end (FX8350 + GTX 970), but Geforce Experience optimised this to the High/Ultra settings and I am enjoying a very smooth 50-60FPS and every effect just looks wonderful.  The scenery is very lifelike, but what really sets the graphics apart from the pack is the lighting.  Every shaft of light and shadow is very realistic and adds a lot to the immersion of the game.

At the time of writing this, I have played about 23 hours of this game, and I would absolutely recommend it to anyone who likes adventure games.  You do not need to play the 2013 Tomb Raider (or any of the others for that matter) to get the story of this one, but I would recommend it just to see what Lara went through in the first game.  You will see what changed her from a naive and idealistic college student to a cold hearted pregmatist who will do whatever it takes to survive.

Play this game.  Now.

reviewText:
RISE OF THE TOMB RAIDER EXECUTES THE FRANCHISE FORMULA WITH CONFIDENCE.

In many ways, Rise of the Tomb Raider could be viewed as a fairly modest sequel. It successfully builds off Crystal Dynamics' excellent reboot, but it doesn't introduce any massive changes; the scope is greater but still in spitting distance of the previous game. But successfully regaining the feeling created in an extremely good game is no small feat. This is the inauguration of Tomb Raider as a formula once more, but for now, it's a formula I'm happy revisiting.

9.5/10

reviewText:
rating: worth buying at sale price (<30€)
score: 7.5/10 - good
similar games: Uncharted, Prince of Persia
tags: exploration, puzzles, third person shooter

Almost everything has been improved compared to the Tomb Raider Reboot from 2013 ... except the story. The story of Tomb Raider 2013 was already REALLY bad and had nothing but forgettable characters. Rise of the Tomb Raider also has nothing but forgettable characters, the story is also really bad, but what ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off the most is how extremely serious this game is. There is NO humour AT ALL, even though the topics and the story of this game are extremely silly things.
Because of this the Uncharted series will always be better.
After the boring prologue I had a lot of fun with RotTR and I thought this might be a strong contender for GOTY, but the more I continued the more I got dissapointed and the terrible story just left me with a dissapointed feeling at the end. Still, the game has a lot of good things about it, which could easily make it a 9/10 just by have LESS story, because it is SO bad.
What I liked the most about this game is how much bigger the areas are, how much more encouraged you are to explore and how much more puzzles you can do. This also makes this game feel much more like the first generation of Tomb Raider games. Combat is also improved, but not by much. Unlike TR2013 though, you don't get thrown into a combat situation and then get attacked by waves of enemies. Here in most situations the enemies won't know that you are there, so you can always plan your attack first and go stealthy. Problem is that the game is so ♥♥♥♥ing easy even on the highest difficulty, actually it's simply broken. You get waay to much ammo and resources for everything which allows you to craft as much poison/fire/explosive arrows as you want, which are by far the most overpowered weapons in the game. With 1 poison arrow you can take down a group of the most armored enemies in the game. Not only that, but you will have millions of healing material, so you can always heal yourself in combat. Especially because of the level design there is always cover which you can use and quickly heal yourself. It gets even more ridiculous when you upgrade your healing ability, which they added because apparently it wasn't easy enough already. With the healing upgrade you can heal yourself almost instantly. I actually didn't die a single time in combat in this game on the highest difficulty. The combat was still fun, and the good thing is there wasn't THAT much combat as in TR2013.
What dissapointed me about the second half of the game is that there weren't these big hub areas anymore, where you can freely explore, do side missions and stuff like that. The second half was completely rushed and you were always attacked by enemies. I completed the game in 12 hours and I did almost all side missions and all tombs except one. 12 hours is really short.
Visually the game was really impressive, it had some really nice places, good variety and panoramas. But I had some frame drops in some places on my GTX 970 which was annoying (without AA, textures no high).

I think if the story and ending wasn't so bad, I wouldn't be left with such a dissapointed feeling and like the game much more. I don't recommend buying at full price, because the game is too short.

reviewText: A grandiose sequel to the 2013 reboot, which was quite superb in any case. I cannot fathom ONE thing that the developers did not improve upon. On the contrary, they UPed the ante. I do not recommend setting up very high textures unless you have quite the beast of a GPU, it really is a fps killer, in comparison to basically every other setting (maybe HBAO+). Final verdict: If you enjoyed the 2013 reboot, youre gonna love this one:)

recommended: screws people's performance on the highest settings. This game needs optimisation still for when it is loading from the drive but most people's performance will be tanking because of Nvidia's usual BS.\n\nSo turn tessellation right down in your driver settings and turn off the HBAO+ to restore most of the performance dips. Make sure you have your pagefile on an SSD

when you are running less than 16GB of RAM. Otherwise do as I suggest and your performance will be mostly fine with everything else on max.

I am running an FX-8120 and a 7950 and I am getting a pretty solid 40-50 fps from the steam counter.

EDIT: Ok so I got to the 3rd part called "Soviet Installation" and my frame rate tanked. I had to drop from "very high" to "high" texture detail. I'm guessing I ran out of VRAM cause that's all it took to bump my frame rate right back up again and I couldn't notice any difference at all at 1080p.
