reviewText:
Rise of The Tomb Raider is an awesome PC game.
Despite this, i would rate the game a 7.5/10.

The game could easily get a 9/10 but due to some significant cons it get the score gave.
Lets go through the pro's and cons:

Pros:

Graphics-
The game looks awesome. The environments are gorgeous, the character models are very well detailed and the pure hair technology looks great. The effects such as the snow reacting to player and to npc is a very nice touch to the game.

Sequences:
Most of the sequences which mainly involve escaping a collapsing cave etc in game are exhilarating.

Customization:
The able to make and wear more outfits is the main improvement in the customization. The alternate weapons and more unique skills also improve customization.

Story:
The story is good but not great though, there are some twist that are interesting but that is all.

Tombs:
One of the letdowns in the previous game(reboot) is that they weren't enough tombs. Rise of the tomb raider improves this aspect and rewards players with very useful rewards for completing each tomb.

Cons:

Framerate
For me, frame rate was very inconsistent. Most of the time it averages at 45fps, sometimes rise to 60, drops to 30,22 and in some cases 15 or even 1fps. The game also crashed in one instance.

Im running on GTX 960, i7-4790 , 8gb Ram and one high preset with some settings at med with tessellation unticked.

I feel the game should be more consistent in terms of framerate


More or less the same:
If you feel the previous reboot was easy, well Rise of The Tomb Raider would also be easy. The same tactics in the previous entry could still be used again, weapons are similar to previous game, not many new tools and they also hardly make a difference.



The framerate was the most frustrating thing about the game as it was inconsistent , this also played a major role in my final score. Despite this its still a got game so i would still recommend it, but make sure you have a powerful rig to support the game and your desired settings.

reviewText:
This game does not give off a good first impression. The beginning is heavily scripted. Walk forwards, watch something bad happen, press X to not die, etc. Follow the linear path, watch the cutscenes. Please, give me gameplay already. Fortunately, after a short attempt to impress players with gee whiz cutscene action, it does start delivering the goods.

The gameplay mixes platforming, traversal (climbing and the like), combat of both the direct and stealth variety, puzzle solving, and exploration and discovery. There's a lot of good to be found in these elements.

Lara's jumping is fluid and fun to control. You can actually aim her jumps a little bit in mid-air, and her climbing is also quite fluid. She can double jump" up walls
hoursPlayed: and can climb icy and rocky walls with her pickaxe. You have a ton of control over these elements
voteText: as opposed to the stiff movement of the later Uncharted games
helpfulPercent: and combining these moves together is a lot of fun.\n\nCombat tends to allow for many options. For example
votesHelpful: at one point I was hiding in water and I grabbed an enemy who was unaware
votesTotal: and drowned him. Then I snuck up behind another enemy
votesFunny: strangled him
commentsCount: and then planted a poison gas bomb on his body
column16: then hid. Another enemy examined the corpse
column17: and got a face full of poison gas for his trouble. Three enemies down
column18: still not spotted yet. I knew I was going to have to inevitably fight
column19: so I lit a fire arrow and ignited two enemies at once
column20: and that blew my cover. Well
column21: almost. The enemies started searching for me
column22: and I was able to surprise one more before everyone spotted me and it basically turned into a standard cover shooter at that point.\n\nOne problem
column23: as I see it
column24: is that there's too much open combat in the game that just takes place in linear areas. I think the game is at its best when you have many options at your disposal
column25: but sometimes
column26: you're just forced into standard shooty setpieces before you can move on.\n\nThe level design is a mixture of open areas
column27: and linear setpieces. Open areas are sometimes huge
column28: and loaded with things to do: characters to talk to (such as villagers or rebels in hiding)
column29: wild animals hanging around their turf
column30: caves to explore
column33: and your eventual goal that takes you to the next area. These areas are fantastic
column34: and I really wish there were more of them.\n\nThe pacing changes up a lot; sometimes you're progressing through a linear area and fighting through enemies
column35: then you have to climb and move through to the next area
column37: and eventually you're out in the open where you're hit with tons of things to do.\n\nSometimes
column39: the pacing doesn't quite work out. One area of the game had a village full of people preparing for a huge battle against invaders. There was a lot to do there
column40: and their upcoming battle was played up as if it was going to be epic. I was really excited about the idea of fighting enemies in such a massive
column43: caves and houses... but when it came time for the battle
column44: it was just a linear cover shooter segment. When it was all over
column45: the villagers were talking about the heavy losses they suffered over the past 10 minutes. I was left thinking
column46: "That's it?!" It could have been epic
column47: but it failed.\n\nYou'll encounter some brutally tough puzzles
column48: many of which are optional (the "challenge tombs")
column49: some of which are required to progress. They involve things like transporting an explosive to its destination
column50: moving a boat around a rapidly flowing river with the help of ropes and pulleys - some puzzles require timing
column51: while others don't.\n\nThe game provides hints in several ways
column52: such as music that changes depending on how close you are to solving the puzzle
column54: and the ability to "examine" things using "survival instincts" (which makes important and interactive things glow
column55: while also revealing objectives).\n\nThere's also tons of hidden secrets to find. The game outright alerts you to nearby "challenge tombs"
column56: with the sound of wind chimes playing when you're in their general area. The tombs are essentially multiple puzzles: first you have to find them
column57: then you have to enter them
column58: then you have to solve the puzzle inside. Successfully raiding the tombs earns you special abilities
column59: such as the ability to detect animals' hearts and kill them in one hit if you shoot them there (animals are very nasty and harder to kill than most humans
column60: so this helps a lot in encounters with them).\n\nYou can backtrack to find secrets and hidden things in locations you've been to before
column61: using your new abilities. Any campfire you've previously visited serves as a place to upgrade weapons and spend experience points (obtained via collecting items or killing in special ways) on skills
column62: as well as warp to any previously visited campfire
column63: so you can backtrack that way.\n\nThe skills you can obtain are things like the ability to turn gas cans into bombs
column64: the ability to craft certain kinds of new weapons (such as explosive arrows)
column65: and more. Some of these skills really open up your combat options
column66: and there are also special abilities that can be obtained only by completing challenge tombs.\n\nThat said
column67: this game has some things that hold it back quite a bit. A lot of the cover-based combat just feels
column69: mostly like it's just there for the sake of being there
column71: while stealth combat is a lot more fun but doesn't quite go on for as long as I'd like at times. There are scripted moments that are just really unnecessary
column72: but at least it's not as bad as the previous game when it comes to that (save for that awful beginning).\n\nAnd the ending feels rushed and generic. Lots of ghost-like enemies shooting at me with blue fire arrows that are just easier to kill and do way less damage than you'd expect. I felt like I didn't have much opportunity to do much creative fighting
column73: and it just felt like a waste of time. And the final area even goes for that annoying orange/blue color scheme Hollywood is obsessed with (Google it to see what I mean if you haven't noticed that trend already). Indeed
column74: rushed endings are a problem I've noticed in other games I've really enjoyed lately
column75: such as Axiom Verge and Life is Strange. It's like companies just feel the need to make their game end on a big note
column76: but don't know how to do it in a way that paces well.\n\nFinally
column77: and this is more of a mild complaint
column78: enemies can be total morons at times. At one point
column80: and there was a fire burning next to me. An enemy was walking towards my hiding spot
column81: about to turn the corner to where I was hiding
column82: and he walked right into the fire
column84: and died seconds later. I've seen other behavior that's not quite that stupid
column86: other than some issues with pacing and scripting
column87: overall I think this game is pretty good
column88: and a major improvement over Tomb Raider 2013. If you're looking for an adventure with a lot of different types of gameplay
column90: since I think the good outweighs the bad.\n\n(Finally
column91: ignore my number of hours on record. I tend to leave games running the entire time I do other things)"

reviewText:
I had mixed feelings while playing the game but in the end I considered it deserves a good review.

Weak points:
-First to mention is the horrible performance on AMD videocards (R9 280X), Tomb Raider 2013 war running mostly around 100fps at max settings, the Rise barely runs 30 at medium in most of the missions. It's hard for me to understand why the graphic engine has such a big performance drop without having a huge progress in graphics quality. But when you run the game you can see Nvidia logo... this says something...
-Main story is not as strong and captivating as in previous game.


Strong points:
-The backstory is great, the world is filled with recordings from multiple parts of history that I enjoyed listening to, i found them more captivating the game's main story.
-Lots of weapon and gear customization options
-Lots of collectibles and multiple side-missions that made me spend time outside main story missions
-Amazing gameplay and well-made animations combined with beautiful and easy to understand levels... this is probably what makes Tomb Raider pretty unique.

Also worths mentioning:
The game has no multiplayer, but even if it had, would not be a big +, it's not that kind of gameplay I'd want for online. Anyway they added some interesting singleplayer mods that might steal you many hours

reviewText:
If you spoke to me when I was a kid and told me that one day there would be Tomb Raider games where Lara Croft didn't use her iconic dual Desert Eagles but she instead swapped them for a Bow, I would shun you and probably throw a tantrum.
But here I am in 2016, having just finished the second game and I am beyond amazed. This game takes the best aspects from the last game and adds things we all missed from the original games... RAIDING TOMBS!

PROS
-Great Graphics
-Amazing gameplay. Especially the crafting system when in combat
-Pretty solid story that keeps you intrigued
-You can finish the entire game with the Bow. The weapons found later on in the story were not automatically superior

CONS
-Constant hunting in areas for things like coins or strongboxes tends to get boring
-Combat was never really challanging. Bears were more of a challange than 10 or more Trinity Soldiers
-Framerate drops in movies (under 20fps for me in some places)

As a Tomb Raider fan since I was just out of nappies, who started his first Tomb Raider experience by being allowed to sit on my brothers lap and press the space bar to draw Lara's weapons when she needed to them, I Definitely think this game is a game worthy of the Tomb Raider name and any one who is a fan of the originals or just the newer ones should give it a playthrough.

OVERALL SCORE 9/10

reviewText:
This is a good sequel, I really enjoyed the premise. Especially the bits in Syria and early on in Serbia on the mountain felt really awesome, great introduction set pieces. The puzzles are a bit too simple honestly but I was fine with it as is.

My biggest gripe was how several times while far into the game I had to restart it. There are bugs here, nasty ones at that. Probably not everyone experience them but sometimes events weren't triggered, especially towards the end. The trebuchet stuff was downright frustrating, I had to restart the game several times. Not because of death mind you, simply because NPC's would be stuck inside walls and keep throwing stuff at you but you couldn't kill them. Or I couldn't remove debris that was in the way because it didn't get removed even though I was doing what I was supposed to do to progress. So really the last bit was really annoying for me. However these are bugs that will probably be fixed or may not occur for everyone. Though I really hated the trebuchet stuff in general, going back and fourth between these felt like pure filler to try and make the game longer.

As for the rest of the game, it's quite stunning and has an engaging story. Some pieces are quite cool, where you had three factions fighting each other at the end and you're just trying to make it across to the other side with things blowing up infront of you.

I must admit though I was expecting more, Rise of the Tomb Raider feels like the other Tomb Raider game from 2013. I guess more of the same is good?  But I would have liked to see them open up the world a bit more, I understand that is difficult.  Especially when there are events sometimes in tombs that block off areas as you progress.  It's not a big thing but the only time I really felt like I was exploring was when I found tombs scattered around the map for the side missions. These are done very well and I highly recommend doing these, most of the time they are a lot more engaging than the main mission stuff.

I'll end with that it's a solid sequel that needs some bug fixes and next time around maybe opening the world up more.

reviewText:
More varied, more fun to play version of a reboot from 2013. A modest sequel and a refinement of Tomb Raider formula, a formula I had a lot of fun revisiting. There are new areas to explore, plenty of side activities to do, myriad of things to collect, and a new group of enemies ready to be headshotted. There is also a brand new story, this time centering around the Divine Source, mythical artefact that supposedly can grant eternal life.

Optional tombs were also improved. They are more memorable, make much more sense in the game world, and no longer award you with experience points but rather teach Lara new abilities. It was a joy to find and clear them all.

Multiplayer was thankfully neutered and replaced by Expeditions - new set of modes, allowing you to replay chapters, play score-attack or return to hub areas with new objectives - all while competing with other players on leaderboards. I'm also happy to report that ridiculously brutal death scenes have been seriously toned down.

My biggest problem with RoTR is that it is too similar to its predecessor. On the next instalment (and I'm sure there will be one) I'd like some serious game play changes and not just a paint job.

TL;DR - Solid game, bad tombs and AI, predictable and short story - 7/10

reviewText:
My overall rating for Rise of the Tomb Raider(tm): 95/100 (RotTR)

It was expected, that since publisher change occured to Square Enix in 2009, we might get a restart of Tomb Raider series. Fortunately, it was a good one, with enhanced graphics and thrilling story. Developers went even further and gave us in this title also exploration and survival challenges in harsh Siberian nature. Game, what may calmly aspire to the Game-of-the-Year title. Lets see in detail, what went good and what might be better.

GAMEPLAY

+ Respect to tradition
+ Thrilling story
+ New platforms and puzzles
+ Good locations allowing non-linear gameplay
+ Exploration possibility
+ Completable achievements
+ DLC serve their purpose, purchasable with in-game earned credits
+ RPG elements and multiple tactics
o nVidia cooperation
- Sometime controls are clunky
- Game is less intuitive

It is always hard to release a title in such famous series as Tomb Raider. Developers from Crystal Dynamics succeeded to give us a stunning story and yet perserve the spirit of previous titles. Furthermore, we can see, how it all begun, de facto, it is a restart of the whole serie.

RotTR respects platform and puzzle presency and incorporates them well. This features present challenges, without them it would not be possible to enjoy this title. There simply have to be traps in tombs, but they are spottable and you have to try a bit to solve them, after that, the player is rewared with success.

What is also positive, that the gameplay is non-linear, gives the player possibility to explore and set own tempo in progressing the game. It is underlined with human vs. nature challenge, your enemies are also beasts and harsh nature, yet resources for weapons, equipment and crafting are taken from vasts of Syria and Siberia.

RPG elements are a great addition, you have three skill trees - Brawler (melee), Hunter (long-range), Survivor (hunting and endurance), which allows you choose your best tactics from plenty available.

Achievements are completable and they serve as another motivation to play the game and advance your limits higher. Here we also go to some negatives.

Controls are sometimes clunky and game should be more intuitive and correct minor deviations. E. g. you are facing milimeter to the side, you will fall and challenge might be broken or not completed.

Cooperation with nVidia was a perfect idea, game runs with an amazing graphic, but sometimes Steam and graphic overlay were causing unexpected crashes of the game. This should be temporary, so far disabling of this feature helps.


CHARACTERS

+ Lara Croft
+ Jonah
+ Jacob
+ Sofia
+ Constantin
+ Ana
o Trinity and Remnant Resistance

Many characters are undergoing a huge transformation in the game. Lara was shy and naive in the beginning, after all of her adventures, she became determind and devoted to do the right thing. Jonah serves as an excellent companion. Mots surprising is Jacob. From the chief of Remnant Resistance forces he became the biggest plottwist, which can surprise even after so many stories told from Lara Croft's universe. Not to forget Sofia, who turned from rebel to person, who might lead the whole resistance.

Constantin and Ana were pefrect opponents, even between them struggles occured. What is sad, the rest of both forces were just to add enemies and allies to give the players immersion of something bigger. Little more improvement and it would be unbeatable.

VISUALS

+ Sceneries
+ Lara's behaviour
- Minor glitches

Sceneries are amazing, either desert Syria or winter Siberia, I could feel the atmosphere in each of my steps. What I like more that after getting from water she did up her hair and when she was cold, she was shivering (not good during the hunt :-D) and holding her arms around her. To sum up this idea, each screenshot might serve as a wallpaper.

There were several minor glitches, fortunately nothing disturbing, so I did not count them to evaluation.

SOUNDTRACK

+ Fitting to the game
+ According to the atmospheree

Another great composer work, songs are changing accordingly, atmosphere is kept in the level, that player is always amazed. Also, change of music sometimes warns you before you actually encounter enemies or beasts.

SUMMARY

To sum it up, RotTR is a great game, that might catch even players out of this genre (my example), is really customizable and players are able to enjoy it in their own tempo. Story is perfect, enviroment as well, it is up to you, whether you choose to explore or to progress.

In case you want to examine your survival activites, try Endurance mode, or uncover the truth behind the myth in Baba Yaga. It is up to the players, which tactic they choose and how they do. Challenges are motivating to go even further, replayability is great.

The prize might be a bit higher (49,99 EUR + 27,99 EUR for Season Pass), but it is completely worthy. Compared to the content and other games, it is really rich in what to offer.

Strongly recommended, and in my humble opinion, perfect aspirant for the Game of the Year.

reviewText:
A nice balance of gameplay, story, and collection. I liked Tomb Raider 2013 and praised both the smoothness of the character's movement through the game and how, while there was much to collect, it isn't overly burdensome for completionists. Yes, I do use guides for a few hard-to-find pieces (my rule of thumb is when it's not fun, break out the Gamefaqs or IGN guides...), but you can get most things yourself with a little extra effort, and it's not a complete pain in the butt.

Rise of the Tomb Raider just smoothed out the rough edges from 2013. So, if you like 2013, you're going to find more to like in Rise. They also toned down the death animations (there's less torture-porn, as I call it), and really let Lara into her own.

I'm also a sucker for the outfit changes (some functional variations, yes, but mostly aesthetics and immersion), and I was pleased to see that there was virtually no fan-service. Yes, her butt looks good in everything, but there's nothing overly showy or sexualized, which is always nice to see with female game characters. Everything else, however, was absolutely eye-candy. Roaming the map was simply beautiful, and the fluid animation of character movement was a joy.

Whole-hearted recommendation from me.

reviewText:
This game is a masterpiece of it's kind.

First of all we have a title correctly imported in the pc code not like many other titles that fail to do so nowadays.

Fantastic graphics, very nice story, balanced fights and smart puzzles to proceed the levels.

Graphics: We all knew from the previous title of 2013 that graphics were the strong point of the new Tomb Raider reboot but nobody could imagine such an advance.

reviewText:
Finish the game 100% completion twice, on second hardest difficulty, and hardest difficulty(survivor).
A great game, definitely recommended it.

+ Graphic is really good.
+ The game play is exciting, there are a lot of tense moment when Lara run into lots of enemies or the structure is collapsing etc.
+ More weapons, there are different type of bows, which provide different stats. Same goes to other weapon such as pistols.
+ More upgrade (inventory, weapon upgrade, ability upgrade)

- Main story line is short. (Game still can be play for a long time if want to get 100%)
- Main story line still can be better. HUGE SPOILER ALERT Some main story line aspect are repetitive with TR2013. Stormguard n Deadless army; Sun Queen n Divine Source
- Optimization still can be improved. It took minutes to load larger maps. Running on i7-4770/R9 280x
There are 2 parts in the main story where after loading large map is continued by cutscene. The cutscene will          lag for 1-2 minutes in my case.

Neutral/subject to personal
= Get all upgrade in survivor difficulty take times. It might get boring, but i am okay with it.
= Natural Instinct too powerful, highlighted too much key item/location for event like tomb exploring.  Every pieces that need to be climb in the observatory are highlighted.
= Final battle is LMFAO. HUGE SPOILER ALERTseriously? Konstantine only took Lara bow, and her pistol/shotgun/MG all gone with the bow? What a powerful steal from Konstantine.
= Lara look more stunning in TR2013. LOL

Anyhow it is really a great game. If you enjoy TR2013, you probably enjoying this one too. Recommended.

reviewText:
I had mixed feelings while playing the game but in the end I considered it deserves a good review.

Weak points:
-First to mention is the horrible performance on AMD videocards (R9 280X), Tomb Raider 2013 war running mostly around 100fps at max settings, the Rise barely runs 30 at medium in most of the missions. It's hard for me to understand why the graphic engine has such a big performance drop without having a huge progress in graphics quality. But when you run the game you can see Nvidia logo... this says something...
-Main story is not as strong and captivating as in previous game.


Strong points:
-The backstory is great, the world is filled with recordings from multiple parts of history that I enjoyed listening to, i found them more captivating the game's main story.
-Lots of weapon and gear customization options
-Lots of collectibles and multiple side-missions that made me spend time outside main story missions
-Amazing gameplay and well-made animations combined with beautiful and easy to understand levels... this is probably what makes Tomb Raider pretty unique.

Also worths mentioning:
The game has no multiplayer, but even if it had, would not be a big +, it's not that kind of gameplay I'd want for online. Anyway they added some interesting singleplayer mods that might steal you many hours

reviewText:
What can I say? I got this game for free with my graphics card, and hoping that they would have improved on TR2013 I decided to play it to see if they made any improvements to the reboot (instead of giving the code to someone that acutally wanted to play the game), but there was nothing new to be found. It felt like it could very well have been an expansion pack to the original TR2013. The shooting is still bad. The guns still sound like BB guns, and the controls are as bad and unresponsive as they were in TR2013. I can not comment too much on the story since I only played three hours of it, but what I got was boring and not very original. The one improvement I found was that they had cut down on the QTE's, but they still used them to much for my taste.

Graphics wise the game is great. Nothing more to say really. The game went for a photo-realistic look instead of having an unique artsyle, which means the game will look old in an year or two. I always prefer when a game chooses to have a nice artstyle instead of going for photo-realistic graphics, since games that have a nice artstyle age way better. Just look at Wind waker. That game still looks great to this day.

And tombs. Tombs where boring. I got trough two of them before I decided to uninstall the game, and they were both way too easy. The game holds your hand way too much. If you are presented with even the simplest of puzzles, the game will have Lara comment on what she needs to do to solve it, which completely ruins the whole point of having a puzzle. This segment will represent the process of getting trough a tomb in this game:

''Hmm, I wonder what I need to do to get past this part?'' I wondered as I was presented with a puzzle.

''Why not do that and then that to solve it?'' Lara then said and the puzzle had solved itself for me.

I hate when games treat their players as if they are two years old, and this game does it exceptionally well.

This is very subjective, but I don't Laras' voice actor. I don't know what it is, but I find it unbearable to listen to her for more than 5 seconds at a time.

If you liked the original TR2013, you will like this. But if you did not, you should pass on this glorified expansion.

reviewText:
Couldn't See It....White Jesus.

If you played Tomb Raider 2013, you get the idea of what's to come in Rise of the Tomb Raider. Amazing scenery and dramatic playable cutscenes are abundant throughout the campaign, but never leave you feeling like the gameplay is bogged down or linear. Explosions and lascerations abound, and really make you feel the resilliance and determination of Lara Croft as she attempts to outwit her hostile surroundings.

The narative of Lara Croft, although at times a bit too emotional for a character that has long been a silent badass, leads well into the story of the games that would follow. This game is great as a standalone entity, or even coupled with it's 2013 predecessor, however for a real fan of the series it makes Lara feel far too soft and under-confident at times.

The combat is smooth, and the control scheme is seemlessly meshed into a few buttons, making the player feel the power of all the tools at ones disposal without an overcomplicated control scheme. It does not, however, do anything to improve or innovate on the standard 3rd person over the shoulder" shooter that we've come to know. In that sense it falls short of the rest of the overwhelming accomplishments this game makes
date: and feels more like an "if you've played one..." scenario.\n\nThe graphic demands of this game are high
recommended: a fact that was not lost on me when it (surprisingly) defaulted to "High" settings on my pc. I was very pleased to find out that my somewhat dated machine could run this game at reasonable specs. However early into the first cutscenes I realized that the game had made a bit of an over-estimation

reviewText:
Disclaimer: My first Lara Croft game and thus the review is from a first timer perspective. Also, still only 25% into the game. Will update the review as I progress further if required.

Pros:
1. Beautiful graphics if your system can handle it, especially in areas without Sunlight (see first point under cons below).
2. A somewhat difficult game as it throws many enemies at you in spurts. Note that I am not used to shooting or FPS games so this might not be valid for you.
3. Interesting story line.
4. Tombs with nice puzzles.
5. Voice acting is nice but even though the setting is Siberian/Russian, voice acting is in English with what feels like American accent to my untrained ears.
6. The Skill tree seems interesting and it does not look like you will acquire everything by end game. So its a question of which" rather than "when" which is good.

Cons:
1. In areas with sunlight and shadows (parts of Soviet Installation in the early game)
date:
things are not optimized and actually the game doesn't look particularly good as well in those areas.
2. Few bugs which should be sorted in the first few patches.
3. A high end PC required as the game is graphically demanding and not exceptionally optimized.
4. The game gave me 0 credits for completing the first tomb instead of 10000 credits I should have earned. Actually
recommended: got a popup saying "Earned 0 credits" :). Nothing major but still no answer from technical support after multiple tries.\n\nFinal Verdict : 9/10. Recommended buy if your system can handle it."

reviewText: THe first 20 hours I found myself thinking this game was a buggy,  lesser version of the 2013 TR release. However, once you get over how weird Lara's face looks, the horrendous mouth animations during dialogue both in and out of cinematic, that's when the game actually has a new sort of charm.\nIt might take a few tries to get your grpahics to where your sweet-spot is, but a lot of the issues reported have not happened to me and I always fine tune my settings instead of assuming one-size fits all. I'd describe it as VERY HIGH settings with the exception of one or two parameters.\nThis game comes into its own where the alst one failed miserably: multiplayer. You don't play against others on the same map, no. But you do have an arcade style leaderboard and expeditions menu which offers huge amounts of customizations via cards. It's incredibly addicting and I've spent too much time trying to get the high scores and I will spend more.

reviewText: Rise of the Tomb Raider's level design and pacing make it a masterpiece among action-adventure games. The levels are built to be replayable but doesn't make it obvious the first time through. This makes it feel like everything you do will constantly drive the game forward but never closes you off from collectibles or going back to take screenshots after the action is through, which the jaw-dropping art will make you want to do. The pacing conveys the sense of urgency mirrored in the story but speeds up and slows down effectively. Characters are developed in audio logs as well as in cinematics and interactions with Lara. This teired approach allows you to get a feeling about the characters without being overbearing. This game also brings Tomb Raider closer to it's roots after the 2013's origin story, Lara is back to treasure hunting fiend she used to be. The length of the game hit the sweet spot of ~30 hours for 100% completion run, including the Baba Yaga dlc, and can be extended through the Replay and Endurance gamemodes. Thank you to developers for such an amazing and bug-free experience. (well worth noting in this era of releasing unfinished games) I think this game is a big win for everyone involved and probably the best Tomb Raider game ever. Well worth the launch price.

reviewText:
Excellent Game!

Up until 2013, the Tomb Raider franchise as a whole had been steadily declining since it's glory days on the PS1.  I loved those early games, but the sequels got stale over the years.

The 2013 Reboot was a breath of fresh air, and one of the best reboots of all time, alongside J.J. Abrahms 2009 Star Trek.  I immensely enjoyed Tomb Raider, and after owning it on PS3 (multiple playthroughs) I purchased it on a Steam sale and completed another playthrough.

This game is even better in my opinion than the 2013 Tomb Raider.  In the first game, Lara was constantly on the brink of death, always running and seemingly fighting a neverending uphill battle.  This time, it really feels like she is where she wants to be, and much more in control than in the first game.

The controls are wonderful, I use a xbox controller and it feels very nice.  The Tomb puzzles are not too tough and are completed fairly quickly, which is very good as it doesn't bog down the gameplay and keeps up the pace.  The combat is nice, and there are more weapons and options in this game than it's direct predecessor.

The combat is well paced, with very well directed set pieces throughout.  The game doesn't slow down too much, even when I take a break to hunt more deer or rabbits for the next crafting upgrade.

The Graphics.  Oh God the graphics.  This game is absolutely beautiful.  I wish I could post a screenshot in this review.  My specs aren't bleeding edge or top-end (FX8350 + GTX 970), but Geforce Experience optimised this to the High/Ultra settings and I am enjoying a very smooth 50-60FPS and every effect just looks wonderful.  The scenery is very lifelike, but what really sets the graphics apart from the pack is the lighting.  Every shaft of light and shadow is very realistic and adds a lot to the immersion of the game.

At the time of writing this, I have played about 23 hours of this game, and I would absolutely recommend it to anyone who likes adventure games.  You do not need to play the 2013 Tomb Raider (or any of the others for that matter) to get the story of this one, but I would recommend it just to see what Lara went through in the first game.  You will see what changed her from a naive and idealistic college student to a cold hearted pregmatist who will do whatever it takes to survive.

Play this game.  Now.

reviewText:
*Posted 2-9-16, after completion of the story.

Rise of the Tomb Raider is the newest installment in the Tomb Raider Franchise. We continue the role of Lara Croft as we adventure tombs in Syria and Siberia. You will enjoy the heart pounding combat, exsquisite artwork and graphical inclinement, and overall beauty of this game. The game boasts a trading station where players can accumulate salvage which is the games currency, in order to purchase better weapons, attachments, and outfits. The advanced skill tree sets work hand in hand with the game, allowing you absolute control over your own play style. I hope you enjoy this game as much as i did.

9.5/10

reviewText: A worthy follow-up to the excellent reboot.  It's basically more of the same as that game, which isn't necessarily a bad thing since why fix what wasn't broken?  Lara's competence is established from the first game and you get to enjoy the benefits of that, as she steadily proves to allies that she can be relied on and - more importantly - to enemies that she should never be underestimated and always be feared.\n\nGraphically it looks great, the setpieces are exhilarating, the setting is interesting and it manages to hit the sweet spot when it comes to collectibles/exploration/upgrading equipment etc.  Here's to more of more of the same for some time to come.

reviewText:
I would like to give this a 9/10 but I just can't.  I would have to give it 7/10 but would still recommend it.  I had lots of fun playing it, but the more I played the more glaring issues came to light.  While they aren't game breaking they are there.

Pros:

-Graphics are amazing
-polished gameplay
-great voice acting

Neutral:
-Story is a typical tomb raider.  While interesting it is sort of underwhelming.  The villains are very well done and well acted but I have issues with Lara's motivations which make no sense at some points and ridiculously selfish.  The twist with one of the charaters is seen hours before it is revealed.

Cons:
- Way to easy.  I played on the second hardest difficulty and Lara is a roiling death machine.  While fun every now and then I breezed through the campaign.  The only time I really died was my own fault when I missed a jump or screwed up a quick time event.
- The last act of the game is very similar to the final act of the first game.  Both involve fights on very similar arenas and levels.  A force of undead that sound very similar even while speaking different languages.  A long climb up a fortress.

All in all I would still recommend but I don't agree with other online reviews that gave it stellar reviews.

reviewText:
As a long-time fan of the Tomb Raider series, I really enjoyed playing this installment! The new gameplay and item additions are fun to utilise, the main problem is experiencing glitches when climbing or trying to interact with certain items but these aren't game-breaking - just frustrating! The controls are otherwise simple.

The game does, however, feel super long. Compared to Tomb Raider 2013, there seems to be a lot more to do in regards to challenges, things to collect, optional missions etc, so the 100% can be tedious to some. I liked the story, but it does seem to feel less 'Tomb Raider-y' than its predecessor, built largely around conflict and not exploration. The 'evil organisation mercenary group' enemy also feels recycled from the last game.

I also recommend the Endurance DLC if you like the survival-type tactics for a quick game, the score attack replays are also nice as they give you new objectives to complete - some extra stuff to play until the next game!

Overall, great game. My only complaint is 'what happened to Lara's face?' ;.;

reviewText:
A bigger, better, beautiful sequel

+Interconnected areas and large hub locations offer hidden loot, tombs, wildlife, and enemy patrols.
+Expanded crafting system: new special arrow tips, bombs, visible gear mods, and craftable outfits
+A boatload of optional outfits
+Larger arsenal: weapons have varying stats and benefits
+Increased offensive options: death from above, silent knife take downs, improvised explosions
+Tombs have impoved greatly in both art and design
+Beautiful art direction throughout
+Dialouge/script improved a bit

+/- Less story focus
+/- New Lara is still actually Rambo

-Puzzles are still easy
-Story is still drab
-Mess of collectables

The three DLC pieces are overpriced, wait for deep discounts if you're interested.

reviewText:
Does not disappoint - happy raider!

Just completed the main campaign and I have to say, the game is very good.  Cinimatic, drama, action and lots of interactions to be had.  I have been playing Tomb Raider since I first discovered the original TR back in the 90's.  The franchise has come a long way and I absolutely love how smooth the storyline is interwoven with great acrobatics and action.  I love that Lara can swan dive again though I haven't been able to climb and do an handstand :-)

Solid gameplay, lots to things to collect, build and fight.  There are so much action above the ground and in such high places that at times I could feel it at the pit of my stomach!  Scary, adrenaline rush and exciting...only wish I could climb, run and shoot half as good as Lara.  Franchise has kept her alive and well and am looking forward to more!!

reviewText: This game was amazingly good. The story wasn't bland and boring get loot get out" like I feard it was going to be. I felt there was a purpose. The acting also was on point. I actually felt for the characters
date:
their emotions pulled me in and breathed life into this game.

And this game doesn't get boring or repettitive which i feel like most games recently suffer. The large map makes up for the different land scapes. One minute im in a tundra. The next im in a desert. Then into a luscious forest. Plus the bonus dungeons you can explore was the most fun and exciting part in my opinion. I loved discovering a new dungeon to explore and solve puzzles that were actually quite mind boggling at times. Then i get an ACTUAL reward for my hard work. Not some collectible that means zilch (unless you're a collector). No. I got upgrades for an arsenal of weapons.

The game play was probably my biggest (and pretty much my only complaint) i felt as though the combat was kinda meh. Hide behind cover

reviewText:
Another great chapter in the new adverntures of Lara Croft.

It develops on the 2013 re-imagining of Lara and is again a high-production, narrative driven adventure featuring otherworldy forces in exotic locations. Visuals are amazing and the quality of the characters, especially in cutscenes, is some of the best I have seen yet in a video game.

Performance was good for me on a 970, 8GB and a 3770K at 1080p. Looking forward to more.

Pros

Amazing Visuals and Locations
Detailed character models and animations
Great Voice and Character Acting

Cons

Survival Instinct makes the game too easy
Occasional FPS drops in specific areas due to CPU bottlenecking.

reviewText:
This is an update to this review, as we've seem some slight optimization patch improvements, as well as more progress into the game.
Rise of the Tomb Raider (So far) has been an absolute blast. It's greatly improved from the first game while adding in great addictions that make it feel fun but not too new.
PROS-
Lara Croft is now just a badass! Action happens pretty quickly in comparison to the first game, which doesn't make the game feel like it's repeating the same routine.
Tombs actually matter! You get perks for completing tombs, which I can't actually remember if it was a thing in Tomb Raider 1, but it definitely made raiding tombs feel a lot more necessary than before.
Hunting is actually fun, what with more types of animals and it being rewarding with crafting.
Speaking of which, crafting is oddly extensive and cool. You can make multiple different sets of clothes, ammuniciation, and other cool things.
Looting is still fun.
Gun play is still exciting and somewhat tactical. I always prefer using the bow and arrow over everything else
This game is absolutely gorgeous. One of the best looking games of the year, easily.

Cons-
The game is extremely graphically demanding. 980's are still having trouble running this at a stable 60 max at 1080p. I'm running a mid range rig, so I had to scale the graphics down to high and lower the res. Game still looks amazing regardless.
The regular difficulty of this game is insanely easy so far. Way easier than it was in the original tomb raider.
The assault rifle/semi seems kinda bad compared to your trusty bow and arrow, shotgun, and pistol/revolver. I hardly bother with it compared to every other weapon.

Overall, I'm really enjoying Rise of the Tomb Raider. It's a great sequel to a awesome game. Hopefully there's more patches in the future that'll give this game even better optimization, as I feel this game should be playable at 1080p with even mid range rigs. Regardless, I highly recommend this game.
8.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I would like to start off by saying I originally played this title on Xbox One. I bought a GTX 980 and recieved it for free.

This game is a humongous improvement over the first. The first Tomb Raider had many plotholes and I cannot see any in this story. It's incredible.

reviewText:
It's good! The graphics, moving foliage, lighting is great.

Few complaints, however:

1. Main campaign is a bit short. I feel like it could've been longer, I finished in 10 hrs of gameplay.
2. Lara's face change. I mean, come on. TR 2013's face was so much better. I don't like the new round-face Lara one bit.
3. Instead of $70, I would recommend to pay $40. For the short storyline, $70 is a bit steep.
4. AMD's TressFX in TR 2013 is a lot better than HairWorks in this one. A lot more of a resource hog is HairWorks.
5. The story, no matter how long it is, is a little cliched. We've seen it all before.
6. The best parts of the game is post-campaign when you're trying to 100% it.

Anyway, I recommend this game. I'm on my way to 100%ing it. Should be fun.

- Matt

reviewText:
I would like to give this a 9/10 but I just can't.  I would have to give it 7/10 but would still recommend it.  I had lots of fun playing it, but the more I played the more glaring issues came to light.  While they aren't game breaking they are there.

Pros:

-Graphics are amazing
-polished gameplay
-great voice acting

Neutral:
-Story is a typical tomb raider.  While interesting it is sort of underwhelming.  The villains are very well done and well acted but I have issues with Lara's motivations which make no sense at some points and ridiculously selfish.  The twist with one of the charaters is seen hours before it is revealed.

Cons:
- Way to easy.  I played on the second hardest difficulty and Lara is a roiling death machine.  While fun every now and then I breezed through the campaign.  The only time I really died was my own fault when I missed a jump or screwed up a quick time event.
- The last act of the game is very similar to the final act of the first game.  Both involve fights on very similar arenas and levels.  A force of undead that sound very similar even while speaking different languages.  A long climb up a fortress.

All in all I would still recommend but I don't agree with other online reviews that gave it stellar reviews.

reviewText:
As a long-time fan of the Tomb Raider series, I really enjoyed playing this installment! The new gameplay and item additions are fun to utilise, the main problem is experiencing glitches when climbing or trying to interact with certain items but these aren't game-breaking - just frustrating! The controls are otherwise simple.

The game does, however, feel super long. Compared to Tomb Raider 2013, there seems to be a lot more to do in regards to challenges, things to collect, optional missions etc, so the 100% can be tedious to some. I liked the story, but it does seem to feel less 'Tomb Raider-y' than its predecessor, built largely around conflict and not exploration. The 'evil organisation mercenary group' enemy also feels recycled from the last game.

I also recommend the Endurance DLC if you like the survival-type tactics for a quick game, the score attack replays are also nice as they give you new objectives to complete - some extra stuff to play until the next game!

Overall, great game. My only complaint is 'what happened to Lara's face?' ;.;

reviewText:
A bigger, better, beautiful sequel

+Interconnected areas and large hub locations offer hidden loot, tombs, wildlife, and enemy patrols.
+Expanded crafting system: new special arrow tips, bombs, visible gear mods, and craftable outfits

+Larger arsenal: weapons have varying stats and benefits
+Increased offensive options: death from above, silent knife take downs, improvised explosions
+Tombs have impoved greatly in both art and design
+Beautiful art direction throughout
+Dialouge/script improved a bit

+/- Less story focus
+/- New Lara is still actually Rambo

-Puzzles are still easy
-Story is still drab
-Mess of collectables

The three DLC pieces are overpriced, wait for deep discounts if you're interested.

reviewText:
The second installment in the amazing, rebooted Tomb Raider franchise. Lara is now in search of the Divine Source, the relic of immortality, as is the illuminati-like group Trinity. The game is very similar in mechanics and playstyle, being a linear driven story with open world exploration with an almost absurd amount of collectibles, however being Tomb Raider that is part of the fun, exploring.

The combat is extremely similar with a new mechanic being introduced, the on the fly crafting and resource gathering for offensive and healing purposes. The similarities are not only in the gameplay and combat, but also in the tombs and puzzles, the only difference being the puzzles seem to have gotten easier to a point where figuring this optional tombs puzzle is as simple as shooting a rope arrow and turning a crank, congrats! you figured out how to use the controls.

The downsides being the overly simplified puzzles and the DLC is not great, an hr long story DLC, and two challenge  modes that arn't particular spectacular.

Overall the game is amazing, fun gameplay and exploration, amazing combat finishers and the return of the brutal Lara deaths. Extremely cinematic with amazing visuals and extremely fun running sequences where everything is falling apart as you leap from crumbling collums to a swinging peice of scaffolding to land onto a cable, only after sustaining wounds that would kill any normal human, as Lara does. 9/10.

reviewText:
This is an update to this review, as we've seem some slight optimization patch improvements, as well as more progress into the game.
Rise of the Tomb Raider (So far) has been an absolute blast. It's greatly improved from the first game while adding in great addictions that make it feel fun but not too new.
PROS-
Lara Croft is now just a badass! Action happens pretty quickly in comparison to the first game, which doesn't make the game feel like it's repeating the same routine.
Tombs actually matter! You get perks for completing tombs, which I can't actually remember if it was a thing in Tomb Raider 1, but it definitely made raiding tombs feel a lot more necessary than before.
Hunting is actually fun, what with more types of animals and it being rewarding with crafting.
Speaking of which, crafting is oddly extensive and cool. You can make multiple different sets of clothes, ammuniciation, and other cool things.
Looting is still fun.
Gun play is still exciting and somewhat tactical. I always prefer using the bow and arrow over everything else
This game is absolutely gorgeous. One of the best looking games of the year, easily.

Cons-
The game is extremely graphically demanding. 980's are still having trouble running this at a stable 60 max at 1080p. I'm running a mid range rig, so I had to scale the graphics down to high and lower the res. Game still looks amazing regardless.
The regular difficulty of this game is insanely easy so far. Way easier than it was in the original tomb raider.
The assault rifle/semi seems kinda bad compared to your trusty bow and arrow, shotgun, and pistol/revolver. I hardly bother with it compared to every other weapon.

Overall, I'm really enjoying Rise of the Tomb Raider. It's a great sequel to a awesome game. Hopefully there's more patches in the future that'll give this game even better optimization, as I feel this game should be playable at 1080p with even mid range rigs. Regardless, I highly recommend this game.
8.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
Great sequel. Anyone who knows me knows I get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off and rage at games very easily and this is probably the least I've raged at a game. It's not that it's absurdly easy - it is, for the record. It's that the puzzles and tombs and platforming in this game were all very organic and logical and there is never a moment where you're wondering where the hell to go.

CD seems to have taken a lot of inspiration from other games like Last of Us with the realtime crafting of explosives and ammo, and all of the new game mechanics mesh wonderfully with the old without feeling like they were added just for the sake of not trying to repeat TR2013 again. For example you collect magnesite to craft exploding arrows, or you can craft them with grenades, and the generic supply system of 2013 has been replaced with one that actually requires specific items from the environment/animals to make certain items or upgrades.

Story is about as good as it gets with a Tomb Raider/Indiana Jones storyline and again Crystal Dynamics has put some work into making Lara feel like a relatable, actual person as opposed to the original Tomb Raider franchise.

The graphics are spectacular, on par with Witcher 3 if not better - especially when it comes to the effects. The hair physics is still completely borked though. You'll randomly see Lara's hair fly off to one side for no reason when there isn't even that much wind, for example, or it will just start moving around at weird angles. It's not much more than a hilarious little detail.

The weapon arsenal isn't much to talk about but you get about 4 weapons per category and they can all be customized with multiple tiers of upgrades, to better kick ♥♥♥ with.  Skill trees from the last game are back too with some slight changes, overall it feels like the same game but with a lot less time spent whining and crying around an island, and more time getting to the action.

This time around the awesome CG intro has been swapped out for a playable prologue that has some of the best visuals in the game, and everything stays entertaining from there until the end.

My only realy complaint is that they said there would be more tombs in this game. The only way that statement is true is if you count every tiny little alcove and cave as a tomb, because I can't remember any of them being longer than any tomb in the previous game, or harder, except the part where you are climbing on the moving observatory parts. There weren't more tombs, it's that simple, but they at least shifted the focus off of murdering everything that breathes and back towards the story and exploring the environment. To the extent that they could.

Would buy again.

reviewText:
Rise of The Tomb Raider is exactly what you would expect from a sequel and more.

In addition to maintaining all the features its predecessor did well, it inroduced several new features that its successor will most surely carry forward. For example, there are more weapons, gadgets, larger map, varried enemies including wildlife, varried ways to defeat enemies, and a great number of things to do aside from the main quest including Tomb Raiding (finally) and one dimensional side quests, and by one dimensional I mean one tier under Bethesda-level quests given that as of late Bethesda's quests have been rather inadequate by RPG standards.

There is great freedom to complete objectives in a many number of ways however the player sees fit. For example, when faced with a puzzle, the player can complete it in several ways (i.e there is no single way the puzzle can be completed, but there is a single correct answer, which is understandably limiting but still a touch of liberty on the developer's part). Another example is the player's choice to complete objectives stealthily by assassinating enemies, avoiding enemies, or slaughter anything that moves, while still mainitaing Lara's vulnerability and feminine stature, while not using her as a sex toy.

The only limitations is slight stuttering or framrate drop in some areas/cutscenes which detract from the brilliant story campaign, and a limited number of other modes aside from exploration (there is a challenge mode, but its rather repetitive)  but other than that it is a must play for adventure gamers.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Product received for free

Expertly crafted and polished action adventure that is very similar to its predecessor.

While far from perfect, I enjoyed the original TR reboot enough to play this sequel.

Here are the things that are better than the original TR:
* No more sudden and therefore hard to avoid traps that kill Lara in gruesome ways.
* No more quick time events in cut scenes.

Here are the things that are worse:
* Story and setting is less interesting.
* The \Crofting" system is overdone.  You can craft ammo from junk that you forage in the middle of a firefight.  This is neither fun nor realistic.  I have no idea why they added this feature.

My main criticisms remain:  The game is "casualized" and almost never offers a situation that needs either skill or creativity to master.  I am playing through the 2nd hardest difficulty including challenge tombs without ever having any difficulties anywhere -- I am 3/4th of the way through now
date:
and my motivation to keep playing is diminishing.


If you have not played the original reboot
recommended: and you want a pretty but still relatively \"weak sauce\" Uncharted for PC
hoursPlayed: play that one first -- it is a bit better.\n\n(Disclaimer: I am not a journalist but I was gifted the key from a colleague for free.)"

reviewText:
A lot of gamers say this game is better than the first one. I disagree. Yes it has one of the most stunning graphics ever made in a game but doesn't go much further.

The story is SO much worse. It's predictable with little to no mistery and the development has little pace differences. To make things worse, the scenarios and dangers that Lara goes through feels all the same: insane elevated areas that keep falling apart and too much shooting. I miss the intriguing puzzles from older tomb raiders. This scenario would be perfect for a lot of good puzzles.

The gameplay is pretty similar but actually got worse because they added so many scattered items all over. I usually enjoy crafting mechanics but the gather and craft gameplay feels like it doesn't belong in this fast paced adventure making it feeling like a chore. Overall, the only really intense part was fighting the bear. :(

tl;dr
Graphics,Performance - 9/10
Sound,Immersion - 8/10
Gameplay - 5/10
Story,Narrative - 4/10

reviewText: Its a review, there will be spoilers.\n\nWow this turned out to be disappointing.  The story is highly derivative of pretty much any adventure movie that has ever been made; from Lara's daddy issues to the absolute rip off of Lost Ark style ending and just doesn't do anything worthwhile.  I can't say the narrative promotes character growth for Lara either because there is a massive disconnect between the gameplay and the narrative.  The story wants you to see the Rise of the Tomb Raider, but Lara pretty much from start to finish is girl-Rambo.  She has sacrificed all of her distinctive style from the previous games to become a Call of Duty soldier, who without any real experience or training, can demolish entire armies on her own.  As an example, there is a historical depiction where the assassin sent by Trinity and chasing the prophet details how he managed to kill one of the deathless of Kitezh but barely survived it, however this comes after Lara has killed at least a half dozen of the deathless" already. reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider is the sequel to the 2013 Tomb Raider reboot and unfortunately, they made little to no improvements over the 2013 game. Infact, I think this game went a step backwards or two. The combat is still somewhat solid but the game is quite easy even on Seasoned Raider difficulty (Second-hardest difficulty in the game by the way). The story is bland and boring and the tombs are still ♥♥♥♥ing optional though they did improve them a little in this game.

The graphics when maxed out look absolutely gorgeous. Sadly, Nixxes (The ones who did the excellent PC ports of Deus Ex: Human Revolution and Tomb Raider 2013) dropped the ball for this pc port. Even when lowering it down to medium-low graphics, the game ran like ♥♥♥♥ for the most part. There's also two specific areas in the game that are so badly optimized that my FPS dropped down to the low 20s and stayed there and to be honest, the areas in this game aren't that much more detailed than in the 2013 game.

Speaking of the areas, Siberia was not as interesting as the island in the first game and wears out its welcome in the first few hours in the game. I honestly thought the prologue chapter starts off a little promising but then starts to lose it slowly when you get to Siberia. In this game, there are NPCs that give you quests but they are mainly just bland fetch-quests which give you some decent rewards that you might need if you're gonna get certain weapon upgrades and stuff. These quests also bog down the pacing greatly and makes the game a slog at times. Honestly, they should cut the metroidvania stuff since it doesn't work very well in these games and they should go back to the variety of different locations in the previous games.

Thankfully, they heavily toned down the QTEs in this game as there are only a few in the very beginning of the game and the very end and they finally fixed the button prompts so that you can actually see which button you are supposed to press. There's also much less combat this time around for the most part until the end which then they just drag on and ♥♥♥♥ing on and you just want it to end. Like the previous game, the combat is just your standard over-the-shoulder third-person-shooter that you've seen in the last couple of years.

There is still hand-holding even when you turn off survival instints and that show game prompts option or whatever its called. Lara doesn't shut the ♥♥♥♥ up and gives you hints while you're doing the puzzles and the puzzles themselves are not any harder than the ones in the 2013 game. The tombs themselves are slightly better designed this time around but most of them are still easy to do for the most part.

The platforming is still as simplified as the one in the 2013 game aside from a new tool or two that spices up the platforming a bit. There is quite a bit more exploration this time around but the areas themselves as I said before, are not that interesting to explore in the first place. Also, why are there no dual-pistol badass old-school Lara moments like they promised at the end of the first game? They just rehash the whole Lara becoming a survivor theme all over again but with no OH MAH GOD
recommended: Rise of the Tomb Raider is a disappointing sequel that doesn't really improve all that much from the first game. If you want more of the same stuff
hoursPlayed: this game will give you some enjoyment out of it but if you were expecting this game to go back to its roots and see Lara become the Tomb Raider we all know and love
voteText: then you will be pretty disappointed."

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider is the awaited sequel to the new defining Tomb Raider of 2013.

Gameplay 9 of 10

Think of it as a mixture of Uncharted and the original Tomb Raider. But with a lot more adrenaline. You (a younger Lara Croft) are climbing snowy siberian mountains, dive into long forgotten ancient sewers (yikes) collect old relicts and fight competing mercenary-vault hunters in the search of eternal life. All the while it is mixed with some ( not too many ) quick time events. And if normal or hard difficulty is way to easy for you ...go try the survival mode. Yes, it's exactly what you think it is. Hunt deer and make shelters to survive. The controls are well designed and feel almost natural.

Graphics 9 of 10

This makes the game really really shine. They are simply breathtaking, from the blazing sun in the desert in Syria to the glistening snow in Siberia. Old murky water actually looks exactly the way it should look. The rays of light, the little animals that surround you in Syria..it's just unbelievable how good and smooth it actually looks. Oh and by the way, it's absolutely bug and glitch free (at least it was to me). Ahem ...I'm not looking at you Batman: Arkham Knight

Sound  8.5 of 10

The Sound was okay. Typical Tomb Raider stuff, nicely integrated into the game, without distracting from the game. Yet, slightly less important than the other categories. Solid work though.


Final Verdict

Definitely a must-buy. Even if you are not a real fan of the series. This game deserves to be bought or at least rented. I can guarantee you will have a ton of fun with the game, wether it's puzzle solving, treasure hunting, or else. GO for it

reviewText:
Verdict: The main story is great, however the side missions and challenge tombs dont feel worth my time, and I'm not compelled to go back to the game at all. If you're okay with spending $60 for a 12 hour game, this game would be perfect for you, 8.5/10.




The game itself is great, however as for other single player games, this would be a hard fought victory to consider it worth your money. I played the game on the default difficulty, fully taking my time and completing some of the optional challenge tombs, and the game only took me 11 1/2 hours to complete. Hours may vary depending on the difficulty, however I do not see it exceeding 16 hours for the main story on even the highest difficulty.

There also isn't much to do in the post game to extend playtime. There are a few other side quests and challenge tombs to be completed, however the challenge tombs arent interesting enough to keep my attention and the quests are a bit tedious.

I personally bought the game for $40 and thought that was an aboslute steal of a deal, however after calculating it myself, I conclude that although even that being 33% cheaper than the list price, it still isn't worth it, unless of course you plan on 100%-ing the game.

reviewText:
After waiting for more than 2 months, after its initial release on the Xbox One. I was somewhat disappointed after playing the game myself. While they point out the high ratings from IGN and Game informer, I myself cannot believe that these ratings were legit.

The story was decent, but I miss the danger that was thrown at you frequently in Tomb Raider (2013), Yet it doesn't really connect with each other, and it would've made more sense if you ask me. What even happened with the crew from the first game? The only one that seemed to return is Jonah, but where is the rest? Lara's immortality already gifted her for not freezing to death or surviving a dozen gunshots to the face. While in The first one you could easily die after being injured.

The upgrades and tools that have been added are fun to use, but I wish that there were more interesting ways to achieve them.
The game's ending was also very disappointing, and even after the credits, it just looks as if they are hinting towards another sequel. Whether or not this is real - I leave up to the others...

But again, the game's ending felt like a flop, not even an intense boss battle, oh no. Instead, you face off against a helicopter which is way too easy to destroy. While in the reboot you had to fight off a stormgarurd that was eager to smash your face in.

The open world is beautiful and it contains a lot of detail. But as luck would take it, graphic card only for the ultimate are able to enjoy the full extend. While we are forced to lower our settings for a stable fps, with no luck. Forcing me to play at a rough 50 fps, with a resolution of 1024x720. so if a GTX 750 TI 2GB doesn't help along, then I don't know what is wrong with games these days. Weird, cause Tomb Raider Reboot ran smooth as butter on high quality settings, but whatever, this is up to the developers.

I guess I can say that I enjoyed playing, but at the same time I wished for a more challenging experience, instead of repeating the same things over and over again.

reviewText: The worst lara croft I've ever played. They spent too much time making trillions of gadgets and forgot about other things. I can't believe the story of this tomb raider is the story of the year. It's full of genre stereotypes and flaws. It is simply boring.  Haven't played on consoles, but the pc version of the game is full of bugs, lags and artefacts. The previous part was almost perfect and they ruined this one. I greatly regret buying this game.\n\nFour high-poligonal asses out of ten.

reviewText:
I've been a TOMB RAIDER fan since the beginning. However, I want to give the most honest non-biased opinion over the game that I can.

Rise of the Tomb Raider. Strange title, maybe they were trying to be cool and give it a Christopher Nolan BATMAN title. Lara Croft neither rises or raids that many tombs in this game, so don't be confused by the title.

Fans of the original TOMB RAIDER series should feel upset yet satisfied with the direction of the series. The current direction of the game is both good and bad for Lara Croft.

On one hand we have a new generation of gamers that are very interested in the game now with the impressive graphics and addicting gameplay elements of collecting stuff while playing as a very sexy, yet ridiculously short, hero named Lara Croft.

On the other hand we have a game that completely alienates the old fans by removing itself almost entirely from the original gameplay that we grew up with and loved. Gone are the days of exploring massive tombs and solving puzzles that required some critical thinking skills. The atmosphere of being lost in an ancient tomb scavenging for survival.

TOMB RAIDER now is a very, VERY casual friendly Easter Egg hunt game with little to no threats. There is ZERO suspense from not wanting to fall to your death from a poorly timed jump and having to revert back to an old checkpoint crystal. Now, you kill Lara just for fun or with lack of concern but you spawn immediately in the same spot. The risk of death is completely zero.

It doesn't even do the Easter Egg hunt thing very well anyways. Most of the time you're trying to unlock everything the game drops in something that says you don't have the right materials to explore forcing you to back track, if you even remember where the Hell it was to began with. It's not natural or well thought out, the level design is terrible because of this. No matter the fancy graphics, this is frustrating beyond means being forced to back track during natural progression areas with invisible walls.

They're starting to take the story a bit too seriously. I would really like to see games start to use some comedic relief. The story in Rise of the Tomb Rider starts to become white noise, especially when Lara Croft talks to herself at every camp fire or when you pick up treasure scrolls with story that is usually unremarkable or uninteresting.

The graphics are  beautiful but is not optimized in the current build.  My GTX 980 stutters in the large map areas like the Soviet Installation. I eventually have to just turn it down to HIGH settings and switch back to VERY HIGH depending on the area I'm in. Sometimes I get 120 FPS on VERY HIGH and strangely for no apparent reason it starts to chug along at 20 FPS for no reason at all.

The combat is boring and non-challenging. I would rather be fighting large beasts, not dudes with guns. This is Tomb Raider, quit trying to be like Uncharted. Shooting dudes in the early TOMB RAIDER's wasn't fun either.

The few amount of Tombs are far too easily to figure out and some are short and uninspired. Each tomb treasure is the exact same model of a sliding book thing with some useless ability you really don't need.

You spend the majority of the game running in circles pressing right-stick in or whatever button you use to that will detect objects in Lara Croft vision. The annoying thing is sometimes it doesn't trigger and you have to spam the button because it turns itself off after you start moving. If I had an ability in this game that will keep Lara Croft vision turned on forever, I'd be one happy dude.

The outfit selection is boring and I think the community would like to see some original outfits return or a customization option to fine-tune how you want her to look.

Lara Croft has a beautiful animated in-game model but that's about the only thing positive I can say about the game. Well I think the ENDURANCE DLC mod has some potential but it still falls pretty flat in its current state.

Sadly, I think it's time to reboot TOMB RAIDER again already or bury the franchise.
